<summary>
* The invention relates to a protective helmet with a hard outer shell and a resilient liner assembly to absorb shock.
	* The liner assembly is designed to be custom-fitted to the wearer's head and can be refitted to accommodate a changed head size.

* The liner assembly consists of multiple layers of elastic thermoplastic sheets with arrays of pockets that are open and unfilled.
	* This design allows for increased bulk compliance and enables the liner to conform more readily to the contours of the wearer's head.

* The liner is fitted to the wearer's head by heating the sheets to a plastic state, deforming them to the proper extent, and then cooling them to a rigid, nonplastic state.
	* This process can be repeated to refit the liner to a different individual or to the same individual with a changed head size.

* The liner is releasably secured to the outer shell by suitable means, such as hook-and-loop fasteners.
	* The liner can be easily removed and reattached to the shell as needed.

* The liner is designed to resist the tendency to shift position on the wearer's head.
	* This is achieved through the use of a comfort foam layer and a sewn knit fabric inner lining.

* The liner is manufactured in six basic sizes to accommodate a typical range of expected head sizes.
	* The liner can be custom-fitted to individual subjects within a particular sizing range.

* The liner does not require the use of drawstrings or the like during fitting or require trimming afterward.
	* This makes the fitting process simpler and more convenient.

* The invention provides a helmet liner that is simple and inexpensive to manufacture.
	* The liner can be easily customized to fit individual wearers and can be refitted as needed.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a multiorifice structure and a method of fabrication, particularly for use in automotive fuel injector valves to atomize fuel in internal combustion engines.
	• The structure is made by fusing concentric layers of solid rods and cylindrical members.
	• Each layer of rods is disposed at a progressively larger angle with respect to the axis of the fused assembly.
	• The fused assembly is then cut into thin wafers, forming angularly disposed passageways.
	• The interstices between the rods and cylindrical members form the orifices through which the fluid is dispersed or atomized.

• The multiorifice structure has several advantages over prior art, including more effective atomization of the exiting fluid and greater uniformity of the apertures.
	• The triangular shaped orifices are more effective in atomization than circular orifices.
	• The surface tension forces acting on the exiting fluid cause it to break up into smaller particles.
	• The uniformity of the apertures is due to the precise tolerances of the extruded rods.

• The structure can be fabricated using a simple and economical method.
	• A central core rod is circumscribed by six or more rods or wires, which are twisted about the core rod.
	• The twisted rods are then sheathed in a cylindrical member, and the process is repeated to form multiple layers.
	• The composite structure is then fused or sintered to form an integral structure.

• The rods and cylindrical members can be coated with a thin layer of material having a lower melting temperature to facilitate fusion.
	• The coating material can be deposited using electroplating, dipping, or vapor deposition.
	• The coating material can be copper, nickel, tin, or any other suitable material.
	• The multiorifice structure can be made from metals, glass, or plastic materials.

• The fused assembly is sliced or cut to produce thin multiorifice structures.
	• The sliced surfaces can be ground or polished to produce a required surface finish or uniformity of thickness.
	• The multiorifice structures can be used in various applications, including fuel injector valves.
	• The structures can be designed to have different angles and configurations to suit specific needs.

• The invention is not limited to the particular configuration and method of manufacture described.
	• Alternate embodiments can be conceived, including using cylindrical members of alternate shapes or rods with noncircular cross-sections.
	• The invention can be applied to various fields, including

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device, particularly an insulated gate (MOS) field effect semiconductor device having a lightly doped drain (LDD) structure.
	* The method improves the controllability of the width of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall, allows for the formation of an LDD structure by a low temperature process, and prevents degradation of the transconductance and increases of the resistances of elements due to hot-carrier injection into the oxide portion on the gate sidewall.

* The method involves forming an insulating film on the gate electrode, forming a conductive layer on the insulating film, and anisotropically etching the conductive layer to leave a portion thereof on the gate sidewall.
	* The conductive layer portion on the gate sidewall is used as a mask to form a high concentration region of the source/drain, and the insulating film on the gate is used as a mask to form a low concentration region of the source/drain.

* The method also involves siliciding a desired portion of the gate electrode or the gate electrode and the source/drain region to prevent hot-carrier injection and reduce the sheet resistance of the source/drain region.
	* The silicided gate electrode and/or source/drain region acts as a portion of the gate electrode through which hot carriers are derived, preventing a reduction of the transconductance of the device.

* The method allows for the formation of shallow junctions and minimization of the size of the device, and is applicable to the manufacture of both n-channel and p-channel insulated gate (MOS) field effect semiconductor devices.
	* The method can be used to form a variety of semiconductor devices, including those with different types of gate electrodes and source/drain regions.</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to Internet telephony and provides an improved end-user interface for Internet-protocol (IP) telephone communication.
	*The invention aims to overcome the disadvantages of conventional IP telephones, such as high cost, power consumption, and echo problems.
	*The invention provides a low-cost IP telephone solution with reduced speech delay and improved signal quality.

* The invention uses an enhanced radio telephone that can be connected to a PC and used as an improved IP telephone.
	*The enhanced radio telephone includes an internal speech coder and decoder, allowing it to operate with a relatively low-performance PC.
	*The enhanced radio telephone can selectively operate as either a conventional radio telephone or an improved IP telephone.

* The enhanced radio telephone can be connected to a PC via a cable or wirelessly using infrared or short-range radio techniques.
	*The connection allows for the exchange of coded speech and control information between the enhanced radio telephone and the PC.
	*The PC performs conversions between the coded speech signals and an appropriate computer network protocol.

* The invention provides several embodiments of the IP telephony system, including systems with and without an external PC.
	*The embodiments differ in how the task of converting between IP signals and coded speech signals is performed.
	*The embodiments provide advantages such as reduced cost, improved convenience, and increased efficiency.

* The invention can be used with various types of network links, including PSTN, wireless radio systems, and public or private data networks.
	*The network interface can be integrated within the enhanced radio telephone or the PC.
	*The invention can be adapted to provide appropriate wireless communication during both wireless-telephone and IP-telephone modes of operation.

* The invention provides an improved IP telephone that is more convenient, economical, and efficient than conventional IP telephones.
	*The invention eliminates the need for a high-end PC and reduces the complexity of the software telephony application.
	*The invention provides a comfortable and convenient handset for the near-end user and reduces echo problems.</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to devices for producing electrical power, pressurized water or other useful work from surface waves on a water body, particularly wave energy converters that capture energy from submerged devices relying on overhead wave induced subsurface differences in hydrostatic pressure and/or enhanced surge or pitch.
	*The invention uses one or more gas tight containers submerged to a depth slightly below anticipated wave and swell troughs, with a fixed depth rigid end or surface held at relatively fixed depth relative to the water body mean water level or wave troughs.

* The containers have a second movable rigid end or surface opposing the first fixed end or surface, separated and connected by and sealed to a flexible, gas tight, reinforced, elastomer or flexible metal bellows, or a diaphragm or accordion pleated skirt.
	*The flexible bellows and smaller moving surface of the present invention reduces total and moving mass several fold and is, therefore, several fold less costly than prior art devices.

* The invention differs from prior art devices in several major ways, including the use of direct or indirect atmospheric venting, overhead surface floating buoys, and no expensive, heavy, high maintenance, marine debris fouled ectoskeleton/cage.
	*The present invention also uses a force multiplier or leveraged connecting means and/or multi-staged or multiple sequenced drive cylinders to increase stroke while maintaining higher capture efficiency than prior art devices.

* The invention can be oriented vertically, horizontally, or in any other orientation, and can be used in various embodiments, including a submerged elevation sectional view of a preferred embodiment, a submerged elevation sectional view of an embodiment with a hinged movable surface, and a submerged isometric view of an embodiment with multiple partially evacuated or surface vented elongated flexible bellows containers.
	*The invention can also be used with various additional features, including a fixed depth inclined shoaling plane, a fixed wave reflective wall, and a floating surface vent buoy mechanically connected to the submerged container.

* The present invention provides substantial advantages over prior art, including increased energy capture efficiency, reduced cost, and improved survivability in severe sea-states.
	*The invention also allows for the capture of both hydrostatic and kinetic wave energy, and can be used in a variety of applications, including the production of electrical power, pressurized water, or other useful work.</summary>

<summary>

• The invention relates to the field of scraped surface heat exchangers, specifically the mounting of blades onto the central drive shaft.
	• The blades are typically installed on the drive shaft at an angle, with the scraper edge facing the outer tube.
	• The blades are held in place by pins with inner and outer fingers that engage with holes in the blade.
	• The installation process can be cumbersome, especially for vertically arranged heat exchangers.

• The invention provides a method and apparatus for facilitating the mounting of blades onto the drive shaft.
	• The blade includes a first side, a second side, a scraper edge, and a hinge edge.
	• The blade also includes at least one mounting hole and L-shaped locking tracks on both sides.
	• The locking tracks include entry tracks and intermediate tracks that engage with the pins.

• The pins include an inner finger, an outer finger, and a base that is mounted to the drive shaft.
	• The inner finger is narrower than the outer finger and has an angled surface.
	• The outer finger is wider than the inner finger and has a flat surface.
	• The base is typically welded to the drive shaft.

• The installation process involves placing the blade at an angle relative to the pins.
	• The blade is then inserted between the fingers of the pin, with the inner finger engaging with the entry track.
	• The blade is then moved longitudinally until the inner finger aligns with the mounting hole.
	• The blade is then rotated downward into an installation position.

• The locking tracks on both sides of the blade provide interference that prevents the blade from falling off the pins.
	• The tracks also ensure that the blade is installed with the correct side facing up.
	• The provision of locking tracks on both sides of the blade preserves the structural rigidity of the blade.
	• The tracks can be made roughly half as thick as would be required for a single track on one side of the blade.

• The invention provides a significant benefit in that the blades will not fall off the pins, even when the heat exchanger is vertically oriented.
	• The blades can be positioned at the installation angle, slid onto the pins, and then slid downwardly along the pins.
	• The blades will stay oriented and will not slide down or fall off the pins.
	• The invention also ensures that the scraper edge is correctly oriented against the inside of the outer tube.

• The only way to remove a blade is to raise it and translate it in the

* The invention relates to a process and apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine of a cigarette-production and/or cigarette-packaging machine.
	* The detection process uses at least one optical checking element to detect an image of a plurality of cigarettes in the magazine.
	* The image is evaluated by an image-processing device to detect deviations from a reference image and/or reference values.
	* An error signal is produced if a deviation is detected.

* The detection apparatus includes an optical checking element, such as a camera, arranged in the region of the cigarette magazine.
	* The camera scans an image of a plurality of cigarettes in the magazine.
	* The image is evaluated by an image-processing device to detect deviations from a reference image and/or reference values.
	* An error signal is produced if a deviation is detected.

* The apparatus can also be used to register defective cigarettes, such as those with missing filters or bent/broken cigarettes.
	* The image-processing device can detect these defects by comparing the scanned image with a reference image.
	* The apparatus can also detect transversely located cigarettes.
	* The detected defects can be eliminated automatically or manually.

* The elimination process involves detecting a defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarette and actuating an ejecting unit to eject a plurality of cigarettes in an ejecting zone.
	* The ejecting unit is arranged in the region of the magazine and is designed to eject a plurality of cigarettes.
	* The number of cigarettes ejected is large enough to ensure that a transversely located cigarette is ejected in full.
	* The ejecting unit can be actuated manually or automatically.

* The elimination apparatus includes at least one ejecting unit arranged in the region of the magazine.
	* The ejecting unit is designed to eject a plurality of cigarettes in an ejecting zone.
	* The ejecting unit can be actuated manually or automatically.
	* The apparatus can include multiple ejecting units to cover the entire width of the magazine.

* The ejecting unit includes a housing, a linear cylinder, and a carriage connected to an ejector.
	* The ejector has a front wall and a rear wall connected by a connecting rod.
	* The front wall and rear wall are displaced in the direction of the rear wall when the ejecting unit is actuated.
	* The ejected cigarettes drop into a chute and are fed to a tobacco-recycling circuit.

* The tobacco-recycling circuit recovers tobacco, cigarette paper, and filters from the

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a device for interconnecting a high voltage cable with an apparatus and/or with a second high voltage cable consisting of a cable termination and a rigid insulator.
	*The invention aims to provide a simplified connection system for high voltage power cables with ratings up to 400 KV and above.
	*The connection system features a common interface between the cable end and any accessory, between two cable ends or between two apparatus, resulting in advantages such as factory pretesting, reduction of installation time and cost, and simplified field testing.

* The invention features three interface methods: an inner cone concept, an outer cone concept, and a no cone or slight inner cone concept, which refer to the shape of the connector on the apparatus side.
	*The outer cone concept has the advantage of separating the cable connection further from the apparatus, making it less likely for a fault on one side to affect the other.
	*The inner cone concept would allow for a shorter solution outside an SF6 cubicle, but may have problems with coned surfaces when components are made by different suppliers.

* The invention has various applications, including SF6 terminals, transformer terminals, out-door terminals, straight through joints, transition joints, and joints between two apparatus.
	*These applications feature compact designs, lower material and installation costs, complete independence between gas insulated switch gear and cable installations, and standardization.
	*The invention also eliminates the need for oil- or SF6-filled insulators, while maintaining mechanical rigidity.

* The rigid insulator has a conical interface surface with an angle between 15° and 45°, which is essential for optimizing the products and ensuring high operating reliability in high or extra high voltage installations.
	*The angle of the cone is critical for the performance of the insulator, and the claimed angle is between 15° and 45°.
	*The rigid insulator is a key component of the invention, and its design and configuration are crucial for the overall performance of the connection system.
</summary>

<summary>
  * The invention relates to a fixing mechanism for a tool for treatment of a material, such as machining, wherein the fixing mechanism comprises a combination of a tool, its frame and tool holder in the frame of a machine tool.
    * The fixing mechanism can be applied in a wide range of technology, including machining by chipping, such as milling, reaming, drilling, turning, etc. of wood, plastics, metal, etc. as the material for machining.
    * The fixing mechanism can be used in various types of robot applications for production, in the exchange of grippers or the like in other automatic devices, such as apparatus for transfer and treatment of pieces, in pneumatic tools, etc.

  * The fixing mechanism according to the invention is primarily characterized in that at least one of the connecting surfaces in the tool frame and in the tool holder in the frame of the machining tool, extending mainly in the mounting direction, is shaped as a curved surface.
    * The first contact surface in connection with the tool frame and the second contact surface in the tool holder are adjusted to be placed against each other in the operational position of the fixing mechanism, in order to transmit machining force between the tool frame and the tool holder.
    * The tool and its frame can be placed in the tool holder by a very simple movement defined by the curved surface, wherein the connecting surfaces are placed substantially against each other and the contact surfaces transmit the machining force in the mounting direction between the tool, the tool frame and the tool holder.</summary>

<summary>
  *The invention relates to switching circuitry that operates at high speeds while producing low EMI output, particularly for driving display drivers.
    *The invention achieves this by utilizing switching regulator circuits with multiple circuit paths that carry electric current in opposite directions to cancel out radiated noise.

  *The invention also provides additional terminal lines that act to sink any electromagnetic interference (EMI) generated in the outermost paths that are actively coupled to the circuit.
    *These terminal lines are configured as "terminal" paths that are only connected at one end and do not carry current, but operate to pick up any leaking EMI field generated by the adjacent paths.</summary>

<summary>
  * The power system may include a battery having a plurality of cells and at least one controller configured to cause the cells to acquire charge for a period of time such that at the expiration of the period of time, the voltages of the cells are approximately equal.
    * The rate at which charge is acquired by the cells may be different among at least some of the cells for at least a determined portion of the period of time.
    * The controller may determine the maximum capacity of each of the cells, the common voltage needed for each of the cells to support a target drive range, the charge time for the battery pack, and each of the cell's resistive circuitry activation time.

  * The controller may determine whether the pack charge time is greater than the maximum of the resistive circuitry activation times and balance and charge the cells accordingly.
    * If the pack charge time is not greater, the controller may first balance and then charge the cells using any suitable technique.
    * If the pack charge time is greater, the controller may activate the resistive circuitry and enable the battery charger, deactivate the cell resistive circuitry when its activation time has expired, and disable the battery charger when the battery pack charge time has expired.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention is an AC-to-DC converter as lamp power supply that converts an AC input voltage to a constant DC voltage at a predetermined value set by a potentiometer.
	• This converter reduces eye fatigue to a minimum level and protects people's health by eliminating low frequency flicker, high frequency flicker, and electromagnetic radiation.

• The converter includes various components such as input protection circuit, EMI filter, rectifier, filter, converter, output filter, lamp, start circuit, control circuit, biasing circuit, sampling circuit, output protection circuit, feedback and dimming circuit, and input monitor circuit.
	• These components work together to regulate the output voltage at a constant value, provide overcurrent protection, and monitor the input voltage.

• The invention can be implemented in various ways, including different topologies, controllers, and components, and can be used in a wide range of applications such as lighting, computer power supply, TV power supply, and electronic ballast.
	• The power supply can also be designed to have power factor correction, which adjusts the input average current to be in phase with the input voltage, resulting in a power factor of almost 1.</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to a system for controlling daylight and artificial illumination in a space to maintain a desired illumination profile and reduce sun glare.
	• The system uses a sensor to sense the illumination level in the space and a control system to adjust the dimming levels of electric lamps and/or window treatments.
	• The control system can be programmed to maintain multiple lighting profiles, each with different requirements for overall illumination and relations of illuminations in different portions of the space.

• The system can be implemented using a closed loop control algorithm, which uses interior light sensors to sense the combination of daylight and electric light in the space.
	• The algorithm can be configured to adjust the dimming levels of the electric lamps to achieve a desired illumination profile and compensate for the daylight illumination in the space.
	• The system can also be programmed to stop adjusting the dimming levels of the lamps when the desired illumination profile is achieved within a predefined tolerance.

• The system can also control window treatments to reduce sun glare, using a closed loop control algorithm that senses the daylight entering the space through the windows.
	• The algorithm can be configured to adjust the window treatments to achieve a desired illumination profile and reduce sun glare.
	• The system can also be programmed to stop adjusting the window treatments when the desired illumination profile is achieved within a predefined tolerance.

• The system can use a single photosensor or a single averaged reading from multiple interior sensors as an input for the control algorithm.
	• The system can also use multiple photosensors, each sensing a different portion of the space, to provide a more accurate reading of the illumination level.
	• The photosensors can be mounted at different locations in the space, such as near the windows or in the center of the room.

• The system can be programmed to adjust the dimming levels of the electric lamps and/or window treatments based on the time of day and the amount of daylight available.
	• The system can use an astronomic time clock to determine the time of day and the amount of daylight available.
	• The system can also be programmed to adjust the dimming levels of the electric lamps and/or window treatments based on the occupancy of the space.

• The system can be implemented using a variety of control algorithms, including open loop and closed loop control algorithms.
	• The system can also be programmed to use a combination of control algorithms, such as a closed loop algorithm for controlling the electric lamps and an open loop algorithm for controlling the window treatments.
	• The system can also be programmed to use

<summary>
* The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) was created in response to the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks to strengthen aviation security.
	* TSA's primary responsibility is ensuring security in all modes of transportation.
	* The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) established security requirements for TSA with mandated deadlines.

* TSA has taken major steps to increase aviation security, including implementing congressional mandates and exploring options for increasing the use of technology and information.
	* TSA has implemented a risk management approach to guide federal programs and responses to better prepare for and withstand terrorist threats.
	* TSA's Office of Threat Assessment and Risk Management is developing two assessment tools to help assess criticality, threats, and vulnerabilities.

* TSA has focused on increasing aviation security, but vulnerabilities remain in air cargo, general aviation, and airport perimeter security.
	* TSA has reported that an estimated 12.5 million tons of cargo are transported each year, and some potential security risks associated with air cargo include the introduction of undetected explosive and incendiary devices.
	* TSA's primary approach to ensuring air cargo security is the "known shipper" program, which allows shippers with established business histories to ship cargo on planes.

* General aviation is vulnerable because pilots are not screened before takeoff, and the contents of general aviation planes are not screened at any point.
	* General aviation includes over 200,000 privately owned airplanes, and over 550 airports provide commercial service.
	* The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has issued voluntary guidance for flight schools and businesses that provide services for aircraft and pilots at general aviation airports.

* Airport perimeters present a potential vulnerability by providing a route for individuals to gain unauthorized access to aircraft and secure areas of airports.
	* Airport representatives have cautioned that as security enhancements are made to airport perimeters, it will be important for TSA to coordinate with FAA and airport operators to ensure that any enhancements do not pose safety risks for aircraft.
	* A number of technologies could be used to secure and monitor airport perimeters, including barriers, motion sensors, and closed-circuit television.

* TSA faces several longer-term challenges in the areas of risk management, funding, coordination, strategic human capital management, and building a results-oriented organization.
	* TSA has adopted a risk management approach to strengthen security in aviation and other transportation modes.
	* TSA's Office of Threat Assessment and Risk Management is developing two assessment tools to help assess criticality, threats, and vulnerabilities.

* TSA's efforts to strengthen and

<summary>
* The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) have different definitions of lobbying, which can affect registration and reporting requirements.
	*The LDA definition covers only contacts with federal government officials, while the IRC definitions cover contacts with state and local government officials as well.
	*The LDA definition does not cover grassroots lobbying, while the IRC definitions do.

* The LDA definition covers a broader range of federal officials than the IRC definitions for nonlegislative matters.
	*The LDA definition includes contacts with all Members of Congress and employees of Congress, as well as approximately 4,600 executive branch officials.
	*The IRC definitions cover only a limited number of executive branch officials for nonlegislative matters.
	*The LDA definition covers more officials than the IRC definitions for nonlegislative matters.

* The IRC definitions have exceptions that can exclude significant lobbying expenses from coverage.
	*The IRC section 4911 exception for nonpartisan analysis, study, or research can exclude expenses for 501(c)(3) organizations' advocacy on legislation.
	*The IRC section 4911 self-defense exception can exclude expenses for lobbying on matters that might affect the organization's tax-exempt status.
	*The IRC section 162(e) exception for contacts with local government legislative branch officials on legislation of direct interest to the organization can exclude expenses for certain local lobbying activities.

* The choice of definition can affect whether an organization must register under LDA.
	*If an organization uses an IRC definition, its lobbying expenses may be below the $20,500 threshold, and it may not have to register.
	*If an organization uses the LDA definition, its lobbying expenses may be above the threshold, and it may have to register.
	*The choice of definition can also affect the information that must be disclosed on the lobbying report.

* The LDA definition requires disclosure of total estimated expenses for all activities covered by the definition.
	*Organizations using the LDA definition must report all expenses for lobbying covered federal government officials.
	*Organizations using an IRC definition must disclose all expenses for activities covered by the applicable IRC definition.
	*The reported expenses may not be comparable, and may include expenses for state, local, and grassroots lobbying.

* The use of IRC definitions can conflict with LDA's purpose of disclosing paid lobbyists' efforts to influence federal decisionmaking.
	*Allowing organizations to use IRC definitions can result in less information being disclosed than LDA intended

<summary>
• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has been assessing strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions for over a decade, finding that leading companies have achieved substantial savings through this approach.
	• Strategic sourcing involves a range of tactics, including leveraged buying, managing demand, achieving efficiencies through standardization, evaluating total cost of ownership, and better managing supplier relationships.
	• The GAO has emphasized the importance of comprehensive spend analysis for efficient procurement, which provides knowledge about spending, buyers, suppliers, and opportunities for savings.

• The federal government has implemented strategic sourcing practices, including the Federal Strategic Sourcing Initiative (FSSI), but has faced challenges such as decentralized procurement, lack of data, and limited expertise.
	• Despite these challenges, some agencies have made progress in conducting enterprise-wide opportunity analyses and developing sourcing strategies, such as the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA).
	• The GAO has reported that agencies have difficulty managing services acquisition and have purchased services inefficiently, which places them at risk of paying more than necessary.

• Leading companies have successfully applied strategic sourcing to services, achieving savings of 4-15% through tactics such as leveraging scale, standardizing requirements, prequalifying suppliers, and understanding cost drivers.
	• Companies tailor their tactics to fit the situation, considering factors such as the complexity of the service and the number of suppliers, and aim to commoditize services over the long term to leverage competition and reduce costs.
	• The GAO has identified foundational principles for successful services acquisition, including maintaining spend visibility, developing category strategies, focusing on total cost of ownership, and regularly reviewing strategies and tactics.

• The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and other agencies have taken actions to expand the use of strategic sourcing, including issuing guidance and designating officials responsible for coordinating strategic sourcing activities.
	• The GAO has recommended that agencies take steps to improve strategic sourcing efforts, including evaluating the need for additional guidance and resources, focusing on high-spending categories, and establishing metrics to measure progress.
	• The GAO has also reported that adopting leading practices can enable agencies to provide more for the same budget, and that changing the cost culture in federal agencies is essential as budgets decline.
</summary>

<summary>
* The current surface transportation programs in the US are ineffective in addressing the nation's transportation challenges due to unclear federal goals and roles, and a lack of links to performance or outcomes.
	*The programs have been established over half a century without a well-defined vision of the national interest and federal role.
	*Most highway, transit, and safety funds are distributed through formulas that only indirectly relate to needs and may have no relationship to performance.
	*The fiscal sustainability of the numerous highway, transit, and safety programs funded by the Highway Trust Fund is in doubt.

* The federal government should reexamine its role in surface transportation and consider a more focused, performance-based, and sustainable approach.
	*This could involve identifying areas of national interest and establishing clear goals for federal involvement in surface transportation programs.
	*The federal role should be defined in relation to the roles of state and local governments, regional entities, and the private sector.
	*The approach should also incorporate performance and accountability into funding decisions.

* The use of economic analysis, such as benefit-cost analysis, in project selection could help improve results and emphasize return on investment.
	*This could involve requiring grantees to conduct post-project evaluations and creating incentives to better utilize existing infrastructure.
	*Providing states and localities with greater flexibility to use certain tools, such as tolling and congestion pricing, could also be beneficial.
	*Requiring maintenance-of-effort provisions in grants could help ensure that federal funds are used effectively.

* Various funding and financing options could be used to address projected transportation funding shortfalls, including altering existing or introducing new funding approaches, and employing various financing mechanisms.
	*Examples of funding approaches include taxes, user fees, and public-private partnerships.
	*Financing mechanisms, such as bonding, loans, and credit assistance, could provide flexibility for all levels of government.
	*Revolving funds and state infrastructure banks could also be used to finance infrastructure projects.

* The principles of creating well-defined goals, establishing a clear federal role, incorporating performance and accountability, employing the best tools and approaches, and ensuring fiscal sustainability could be used as a framework for evaluating options for restructuring and funding surface transportation programs.
	*These principles could help ensure that restructured surface transportation programs address current challenges and are effective in achieving their goals.
	*The principles could also be used to evaluate the suitability of different funding and financing options.
	*Ultimately, the goal should be to create a sustainable and effective surface transportation program that meets the nation's needs.</

<summary>
• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) engages in three primary activities: aviation safety oversight, air traffic control (ATC), and airport infrastructure development. 
	• The costs associated with each of these activities generally depend on the nature and usage of the specific service FAA provides.
	• The Trust Fund, established by the Airport and Airway Revenue Act of 1970, provides funding for FAA's two capital accounts, AIP and the Facilities and Equipment account, which funds technological improvements to the ATC system.

• The current funding system raises concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency. 
	• The disconnect between sources of Trust Fund revenues and FAA costs under the current funding system raises concerns that the current system will not produce adequate revenue in the future to keep pace with FAA's workload increases and, consequently, FAA's costs.
	• Alternative funding options, such as weight/distance charges, en-route charges, flight segment charges, and certification charges, present both advantages and disadvantages, and the degree to which they could address concerns about the current excise system ultimately depends on the extent to which the contributions required from users actually reflect the costs they impose on the system.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Institute of Medicine published a report in 1993 discussing secret U.S. chemical weapons programs during World War II, estimating 60,000 military personnel were exposed to mustard agents and lewisite.
	*The report led to a series of letters between Congress, the President, and the Secretary of Defense.
	*A task force was established to identify DOD personnel exposed to chemical substances.
	*The task force identified approximately 6,400 servicemembers and civilians potentially exposed.

* The Defense Authorization Act for FY 2003 required DOD to submit a plan to Congress and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to review, declassify, and provide records on Project 112.
	*The plan aimed to identify individuals exposed to chemical or biological substances during Project 112 tests.
	*DOD identified 5,842 servicemembers and estimated 350 civilians were potentially exposed.
	*The information was entered into a Project 112 database.

* DOD's current effort to identify individuals exposed to chemical or biological substances lacks clear objectives, scope of work, and information needs.
	*The objectives of the current effort are inconsistent and have expanded beyond the original task order.
	*The scope of the effort is unclear, and the amount of information to be collected has been expanded.
	*The lack of clear guidance affects DOD's ability to accomplish its goals.

* DOD's oversight of the contractor's activities and results is inadequate.
	*OUSD (AT&L)'s chemical and biological defense office has not provided effective oversight.
	*The office has not visited repository sites to ensure the work is meeting the task order's objectives.
	*The contractor's quality assurance process has not been independently assessed.

* DOD's current effort lacks transparency, and the department has not worked with veterans and veterans service organizations.
	*DOD has not kept Congress and veterans informed about the status of its efforts.
	*The department has not included veterans and veterans service organizations in its current effort.
	*The lack of transparency has negatively affected the level of trust in DOD.

* DOD and VA have had limited success in notifying individuals who were potentially exposed to chemical and biological substances.
	*DOD has inconsistently transmitted information to VA.
	*VA has not used all available resources to obtain contact information for servicemembers.
	*DOD has not taken action to notify civilians who have been identified.

* The process for notifying servicemembers who were potentially exposed is unclear.
	*DOD has not

<summary>
* The Mexican government has been combating the growing power of criminal groups, initially emerging as DTOs in the 1980s and 1990s, with a national priority since 2006.
	*The efforts have continued under President Enrique Peña Nieto, with a shift in emphasis toward reducing criminal violence that threatens the security of civilians and the business sector.

* Mexican DTOs' criminal activity extends to areas including human trafficking, kidnapping, money laundering, extortion, bribery, racketeering, and weapons trafficking.
	*DTOs require a constant supply of firearms and ammunition to assert control over the territory where they operate, eliminate rival criminals, enforce illicit business dealings, and resist government operations.

* Firearms trafficked from the United States are primarily transported overland into Mexico using the same routes and methods employed when smuggling bulk cash south and drugs north across the U.S.-Mexico border.
	*DTOs or their agents typically rely on "straw purchasers" to acquire firearms from federally licensed firearms dealers.

* The surge in criminal activity by DTOs along the U.S.-Mexico border has generated concern among policymakers that this violence is spilling over into the United States.
	*Since 2009, Mexican-based DTOs have been known to operate in more than a thousand cities in the United States.

* The governments of the United States and Mexico have committed to work together to stem the activities of these criminal organizations, including illicit arms trafficking.
	*From fiscal year 2008 to fiscal year 2015, Congress appropriated about $2.5 billion in assistance for Mexico that has been provided through the Mérida Initiative.

* ATF and ICE are the two primary agencies combating illicit sales and trafficking of firearms across the Southwest border.
	*ATF combats firearms trafficking within the United States and from the United States to other countries as part of its mission under the Gun Control Act.

* The Mérida Initiative is a bilateral security partnership between the United States and Mexico to fight organized crime and build the capacity of Mexico's justice sector and law enforcement institutions to uphold the rule of law.
	*Among the many activities supported under the Mérida Initiative, some assistance is provided to help combat firearms trafficking, such as providing canines trained to detect weapons and ammunition, and non-intrusive inspection equipment to detect the flow of illicit goods, including firearms.
</summary>

<summary>
* The National Criminal History Improvement Program (NCHIP) is a federal grant program that aims to improve the accuracy, completeness, and accessibility of criminal history records.
	* NCHIP was established in 1995 and has awarded over $438 million in grants to states, the District of Columbia, and U.S. territories.
	* The program is managed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS) and is designed to support the development of a national infrastructure for the interstate exchange of criminal history records.

* NCHIP funds are used by states to improve their criminal history records and to participate in national systems such as the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS).
	* States use NCHIP funds to automate their criminal history records, improve disposition reporting, and enhance their automated fingerprint identification systems (AFIS).
	* NCHIP funds are also used to support the development of sex offender registries and to improve the reporting of protection orders.

* The use of NCHIP funds varies by state, but most states use the majority of their funds for NICS-related purposes.
	* States that are full participants in NICS tend to use a larger percentage of their NCHIP funds for NICS-related purposes than states that are partial or non-participants.
	* Some states use NCHIP funds to support other initiatives, such as the development of ballistics registration systems.

* NCHIP has contributed to significant progress in the automation and accessibility of criminal history records.
	* The percentage of automated criminal history records has increased from 79% in 1993 to 89% in 2001.
	* The number of states participating in the Interstate Identification Index (III) has increased from 26 in 1993 to 45 in 2003.

* Despite progress, challenges remain in ensuring the accuracy and completeness of criminal history records.
	* Some states still have limited automation of disposition records, which can delay background checks.
	* There is also a need for improved access to records on prohibited purchasers, such as individuals with domestic violence misdemeanor convictions.

* The future of NCHIP will depend on various factors, including the demand for background checks, the need for technological upgrades, and the availability of funding.
	* The demand for background checks is increasing, driven by screening requirements for employment and other non-criminal justice purposes.
	* States will need to continue to invest in their criminal history records systems to ensure that they remain accurate, complete, and accessible.</summary>

<summary>
  • EPA's Oversight of Incinerators at Superfund Sites
	• EPA employs various techniques to ensure the safe operation of Superfund incinerators, including setting site-specific standards for emissions and operations, incorporating safety features into an incinerator's emergency systems, monitoring emissions, and providing 24-hour on-site oversight.
	• EPA requires incinerators at Superfund sites to meet RCRA's substantive requirements, such as standards for emissions, and establishes specific cleanup standards for each incinerator based on studies of the site's characteristics.
	• EPA continuously monitors the air in the vicinity of an incinerator to ensure that emissions do not exceed maximum permitted levels, and uses air monitoring data to adjust the incinerator's operations as needed.
	• EPA's oversight of incinerators at Superfund sites is generally effective, but there are opportunities for improvement, such as implementing regular inspections by RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors and systematically sharing lessons learned from site to site.

  • Recommendations for Improvement
	• The Administrator, EPA, should implement the agency's guidance for having RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators, including the development of a single document specifying site-specific operating requirements and procedures for these incinerators.
	• EPA should document the lessons learned about safe operation from the experiences of each Superfund site where incineration is used and institute a systematic process to share this information at other sites where incinerators are used.
	• EPA should consider implementing additional measures to provide further assurance that incinerators at Superfund sites are being operated safely, such as increasing the frequency of inspections and improving the training of on-site oversight personnel.
	• EPA should ensure that the public is informed about the operation of incinerators at Superfund sites and the measures being taken to ensure their safe operation.</summary>

<summary>
• The SEC's financial statements for fiscal years 2007 and 2006 were fairly stated in all material respects, but the agency had a material weakness and three significant deficiencies in internal control.
	• The material weakness was in the financial reporting process, specifically in the areas of period-end financial reporting, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures.
	• The three significant deficiencies were in information security, property and equipment, and accounting for budgetary resources.

• The SEC's financial management system does not conform to the requirements of OMB Circular No. A-127, specifically in the areas of integration and compatibility with the general ledger system.
	• The lack of integration and compatibility requires extensive manual and labor-intensive accounting procedures, which increases the risk of errors and misstatements.
	• The SEC's financial reporting process is complicated and cumbersome, making it difficult for finance staff to complete thorough and complete reviews of disclosures.

• The SEC had errors in its calculation of disgorgement and penalty accounts receivable, which were caused by a breakdown in manual controls and the lack of an integrated accounting system.
	• The errors were not material, but the process for calculating accounts receivable presents a high risk of significant errors.
	• The SEC made adjustments to correct the errors, but the process needs to be improved to prevent similar errors in the future.

• The SEC had weaknesses in its information security controls, including access controls, configuration management, and contingency planning.
	• The weaknesses increase the risk of unauthorized access to critical hardware and software, and intentional or inadvertent alteration or deletion of sensitive data or computer programs.
	• The SEC has made progress in mitigating some control weaknesses, but more work is needed to fully implement its information security program.

• The SEC had deficiencies in its controls over property and equipment, including inaccuracies in recorded acquisition costs and dates, and unrecorded property and equipment purchases.
	• The errors did not materially affect the balances reported for property and equipment, but they evidence a significant deficiency in control over the recording of property and equipment.
	• The SEC lacks a process that integrates controls over capitalizing and recording property and equipment purchases.

• The SEC had weaknesses in its accounting for budgetary resources, including recording obligations prior to having documentary evidence of a binding agreement, and errors in recording new obligations and deobligations.
	• The weaknesses constitute a significant deficiency in internal control over recording and reporting of obligations, and put the SEC at risk of

<summary>
* The U.S. Postal Service had about 765,000 career employees at the end of fiscal year 1997, with 80,238 in Executive and Administrative Schedule (EAS) positions, making up about 10% of total Service career-level employees.
	*The EAS workforce consists primarily of employees in EAS 11 through 26 positions, with management-level positions beginning at EAS 16.
	*The Service has a corporate goal of providing equal employment opportunities to all employees and competing effectively in the communications marketplace.

* The Service's Diversity Development Department was established in 1992 to foster an all-inclusive business environment and support the recruitment, retention, and upward mobility of women and minorities.
	*The Department reports directly to the Deputy Postmaster General and is responsible for actively supporting diversity-related issues in the Service.
	*The Service's 1999 Annual Performance Plan includes achieving a diverse workforce as one of its goals.

* A study by Aguirre International found that women and minorities appeared to be experiencing problems advancing to management jobs at EAS 17 and above positions.
	*The study stated that it appeared that a glass ceiling impeded the progression of women and minorities to EAS 17 and above positions.
	*However, the report did not explicitly define the term glass ceiling or present convincing supporting evidence.

* The Service developed an action plan to address the diversity issues raised by Aguirre, which included 23 initiatives to improve its diversity program.
	*The initiatives were organized into six functional groups, including diversity policy, workforce diversity, and supplier diversity.
	*The Service reported that it had completed implementation of nine of the initiatives and was on schedule for completing the remaining initiatives.

* The Service collects a variety of diversity-related data, but does not have reliable data on the flow of applicants through its promotion processes.
	*The Service has a centralized, computer-based tracking system in place for the last 10 years, but participation in this system varies across Service units.
	*The Service is in the process of establishing targets and measures to use in assessing its progress toward meeting its diversity goals and objectives.

* The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommends that the Postmaster General ensure that appropriate Service officials capture EEO group data in the Applicant Flow Tracking System (AFTS) and use these data to help improve the Service's diversity program.
	*The GAO also recommends that the Service use the AFTS data to identify any barriers that might impede promotions to high

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) defines a Military Working Dog (MWD) as any canine bred, procured, or acquired to meet DOD's requirements to support operations in the protection of installations, resources, and personnel.
	• MWDs are removed from service when they can no longer perform their duties due to medical or behavior problems, when they are no longer needed by the military, or in other circumstances.
	• The DOD has a process for the disposition of MWDs, which includes a review board that makes decisions regarding the removal of MWDs from service.

• The DOD has a system in place for the adoption of MWDs, which prioritizes former handlers, then others capable of humanely caring for the MWD, and finally law enforcement agencies.
	• The DOD uses three systems to track information about MWDs, including the Working Dog Management System (WDMS), the Central Repository, and the ROVR electronic medical record system.
	• The DOD also provides information to adopters about nonprofit organizations that offer assistance with veterinary care for adopted MWDs, such as the U.S. War Dogs Association.</summary>

<summary>
* The Comanche program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet with a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter capable of performing armed reconnaissance and attack missions.
	* The program has experienced significant increases in program acquisition unit cost, with the estimated total program acquisition cost increasing from $61 billion in 1985 to over $44 billion in 1995.
	* The Army's restructuring of the Comanche program continues to pose risks, including the risk of higher program costs and the risk of production decisions being made before knowing whether the aircraft will be able to perform as required.
	* The program is experiencing technical problems, including software development issues, maintainability concerns, and weight growth, which could impact the aircraft's performance and capability.
	* The General Accounting Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of Defense require the Army to complete operational testing to validate the Comanche's operational effectiveness and suitability before committing any funds to acquire long-lead production items or enter low-rate initial production.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with paper coupons or electronic benefits that can be redeemed for food in stores nationwide.
	• FNS funds food stamp benefits and about half of the states’ administrative costs and establishes regulations for implementing the Food Stamp Program.
	• FNS regulations require that states certify household eligibility at least annually and establish requirements for households to report changes that occur after they are certified.

• FNS introduced several options and waivers to food stamp rules and regulations to increase program access and reduce the reporting burden on working families while minimizing the potential for payment errors.
	• These options and waivers include those related to program eligibility, reporting requirements, extending food stamp benefits to households leaving TANF, and options related to TANF recipients.
	• States can choose to use these options and waivers to simplify the administrative process for eligibility workers and to support working families.

• To monitor program accountability, FNS’s quality control system measures states’ performance in accurately determining food stamp eligibility and calculating benefits.
	• States implement the Food Stamp Program by determining whether households meet established limits on gross income and assets, calculating monthly benefits for eligible households, and issuing benefits to households.
	• The actual amount of the food stamp benefit is based on household income after certain deductions, including shelter, dependent care, and child support.

• Almost all states used one or more options or waivers to change their food stamp eligibility determination process, including options to exempt some or all vehicles from counting as assets.
	• Thirty-three states used available options to exempt some or all vehicles from counting as assets in determining food stamp eligibility.
	• Seven states told us that they used the option to confer categorical eligibility to recipients of TANF-funded services as a way to exclude all vehicles and other assets from eligibility determination.

• States are allowed to use more than one reporting option or waiver, and many states used reporting options and waivers to reduce their payment errors, to ease program administration, and to simplify paperwork requirements for households.
	• Thirteen states used two or more alternatives, including the semiannual reporting option and the waiver allowing quarterly reporting.
	• Some states chose not to use any reporting options or waivers, citing concerns over payment errors and the cost and burden of implementation.</summary>

<summary>
* HUD is the principal federal agency responsible for programs in four areas: housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues.
	*HUD was staffed by 9,386 employees as of February 1999 and has a proposed budget of about $28 billion in new discretionary budget authority for fiscal year 2000.

* HUD provides housing assistance through public housing authorities and private-market housing assistance under section 8 of the U. S. Housing Act of 1937.
	*The benefits of HUD’s housing assistance programs are limited by budgetary constraints to only about one-fourth of those who are eligible.

* HUD provides community planning and development funds for local economic development under its Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) and Empowerment Zone/Enterprise Community Programs (EZ/EC).
	*The funding for some programs, such as those for the homeless, may also be distributed directly to nonprofit groups and organizations.

* The Federal Housing Administration (FHA) insures lenders against losses on mortgages for single-family properties, multifamily properties, and other facilities.
	*The Government National Mortgage Association guarantees investors the timely payment of principal and interest on securities issued by lenders of FHA-insured and VA- and Rural Housing Service-guaranteed loans.

* HUD is responsible for regulating interstate land sales, home mortgage settlement services, manufactured housing, lead-based paint abatement, and home mortgage disclosures.
	*HUD also supports fair housing programs and is partially responsible for enforcing federal fair housing laws.

* HUD’s fiscal year 2000 budget request includes 19 new initiatives and programs that were not funded during fiscal year 1999.
	*Some of these initiatives may have been funded in prior years and fall under various programs, including Community Development and Planning, Public and Indian Housing, and Housing Programs.

* HUD’s proposed budget raises questions about its capacity to manage the increase in new programs and initiatives.
	*Concerns arise due to HUD’s ongoing organizational reform and the need for dedicated resources to plan, implement, and manage new programs.

* HUD’s Section 8 housing assistance program is one of the largest program increases in the fiscal year 2000 budget proposal.
	*The program has been found to have inconsistencies in budget proposals, and HUD has been requested to provide information on shortfall estimates and unexpended balances.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Military Health System, operated by the Department of Defense (DOD), has a dual health care mission of readiness and benefits, providing medical services and support to the armed forces and their families.
	• The system includes military treatment facilities and civilian health care providers through TRICARE, with the Assistant Secretary of Defense (Health Affairs) responsible for ensuring the effective execution of DOD's health care mission.

• The replacement medical center, currently under development, will serve as the only tertiary-level referral hospital for the European Command, Central Command, and Africa Command theaters of operation.
	• The center is being designed with flexibility to expand capacity during surges to handle casualties from contingency operations, with the ability to nearly double its medical/surgical bed capacity if needed.

• DOD officials used beneficiary population data and historical patterns of patient migration to identify the areas served by the proposed replacement medical center, with a majority of beneficiaries expected to receive health care from the center located within a 55-mile radius.
	• The center's design incorporates patient quality of care and environmentally friendly standards, including evidence-based design and Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) green building standards.

• The cost estimate for the replacement medical center was developed using a combination of methods, including expert opinion and parametric models, but was not fully documented, with some costs and assumptions not included.
	• The estimate was found to be substantially comprehensive, but minimally documented, with a need for more detailed documentation of cost-influencing ground rules and assumptions.

• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) recommends that the Secretary of Defense direct the Assistant Secretary of Defense (Health Affairs) to provide clear documentation on how medical planners applied DOD criteria to determine facility requirements and to revise the cost estimate to reflect potential posture changes.
	• The GAO also recommends that the Secretary of Defense direct the Assistant Secretary of Defense (Health Affairs) to update the cost estimate with revised calculations and to more thoroughly document the data, assumptions, calculations, and methodology used to develop specific cost elements.
</summary>

<summary>
* ICE officers exercise discretion throughout the alien apprehension and removal process, with the most discretion used in the initial phases of the process.
	*The initial phases of the process include initiating removals, apprehending aliens, issuing removal documents, and detaining aliens.
	*Officers consider various factors when exercising discretion, including humanitarian issues, flight risk, and availability of detention space.
	*The use of discretion is limited by clearly prescribed policies and procedures for aliens who are investigation targets, such as criminal aliens and fugitive aliens.

* ICE has designed internal controls to guide officer decision making, including field operational manuals, policy memorandums, and training materials.
	*However, ICE guidance does not comprehensively address key aspects of the alien apprehension and removal process, such as dealing with humanitarian issues and aliens who are not investigation targets.
	*ICE has recently expanded its worksite enforcement and fugitive operations, increasing the need for up-to-date and comprehensive guidance.
	*ICE has taken steps to strengthen training for officers, including the development of new training curricula and the revision of existing training materials.

* ICE has designed internal controls to oversee and monitor officer decision making, including supervisory review practices and procedures, and an inspection program.
	*However, ICE does not have a mechanism to analyze information specific to the exercise of discretion, and the inspection program is not designed to analyze information on officer decision making.
	*ICE relies on the judgment of experienced field officers and supervisory reviews to provide assurance that officers' decision making complies with established policies and procedures.
	*ICE has two databases to document officers' decisions regarding alien apprehensions, but the details of discretionary decisions are not recorded in these databases.</summary>

<summary>
* Medicare payments for ambulance services are made up of two components: a service-level payment for the type of transport provided and a mileage payment.
	*The service-level payment is determined by the type of transport, such as an ALS Level 1 transport.
	*The mileage payment is determined by the number of miles traveled with a patient during an ambulance transport and the mileage base rate.
	*Since 2002, CMS has increased the rural mileage rate by 50 percent for miles 1 through 17.

* Providers' costs for providing ground ambulance transports were highly variable in 2010, ranging from a low of $224 per transport to a high of $2,204.
	*The median cost per ground ambulance transport for providers in the sample was $429 in 2010.
	*Providers reported that personnel costs accounted for the largest percentage of their total costs in 2010.
	*The cost of fuel has increased since 2010, which likely increased costs for some providers.

* The increase in ambulance transports from 2004 to 2010 is attributable primarily to an increase in BLS nonemergency transports.
	*Super-rural areas experienced the largest increase in BLS nonemergency transports (82 percent).
	*The increase in Medicare beneficiaries' use of ambulance services did not appear to be caused by changes in the demographic characteristics of beneficiaries.
	*Representatives from one ambulance provider organization suggested that some of the increase in ambulance transports was attributable to increased billing for Medicare ambulance services at the local-government level.

* The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Office of Inspector General (OIG) has explored increases in ambulance utilization and has cited improper payments as one potential cause.
	*HHS OIG found that nonemergency transports, including BLS nonemergency transports, made up the majority of improper payments for ambulance services.
	*HHS OIG also found that Medicare's ambulance transport benefit is highly vulnerable to abuse.
	*Many ambulance transports paid for by Medicare did not meet Medicare program requirements, including transports that were not medically necessary.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Department of Defense (DOD) has policies and guidance in place for the management of SRC I ammunition, including requirements for tracking, physical inventories, and shipment.
	• DOD policy requires SRC I ammunition to be treated as a higher risk than other conventional ammunition, with a higher level of protection and security.
	• The military services have automated information systems for managing accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, but these systems have some limitations.

• The military services have maintained accountability of SRC I ammunition at sampled locations, but there are gaps in service-level guidance and procedures for accounting for SRC I ammunition across locations.
	• The Air Force does not track SRC I ammunition by serial number, but has plans to revise its guidance.
	• The Army and Marine Corps do not have finalized guidance on the required time frame for receipting SRC I ammunition.

• The military services have not consistently ensured timely, complete, and accurate information to maintain full visibility of SRC I ammunition in the continental United States.
	• The Army has not ensured timely and complete information of SRC I ammunition returned to contractors for repair or maintenance.
	• The military services have not always entered timely information in the Defense Transportation Tracking System (DTTS) on SRC I ammunition shipments.

• The Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command and the military services have taken steps to improve the timeliness of data in DTTS, but there are still issues with completeness and accuracy.
	• The Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command has provided reports to the military services on timeliness of confirmation of individual SRC I shipments.
	• The military services have acknowledged the need for improved collaboration to address issues with DTTS data.

• The DOD concurred with the six recommendations made to enhance policy and procedures and improve the accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition.
	• The Air Force will revise guidance to clarify that accountability for all SRC I ammunition items in its custody should be maintained in its system of record.
	• The Army and Marine Corps will finalize and implement guidance on the required time frame for receipting SRC I ammunition.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Social Security Administration (SSA) has a disclosure policy that is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and the policies of most federal agencies.
	• The policy is designed to protect the privacy rights of individuals to the fullest extent possible while permitting the exchange of records required to fulfill its administrative and program responsibilities.
	• The policy is contained in 20 C.F.R. Part 401 and is promulgated through regulations outlined in its "Program Operations Manual System" (POMS) and Emergency Messages.

• SSA's disclosure policy allows the disclosure of information to law enforcement under certain conditions, such as when the criminal activity involves fraud or other crimes in Social Security programs.
	• The policy also permits disclosure in cases involving nonviolent crimes and criminal activity in other government programs similar to Social Security programs.
	• SSA may disclose information when a violent crime has been committed and the individual who is the subject of the information requested has been indicted or convicted of the crime.

• SSA's Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is authorized to disclose individuals' personal information to law enforcement agencies under a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with SSA.
	• The OIG can disclose whether a given name and SSN match the name and SSN in records at SSA, referred to as SSN verification.
	• The OIG is permitted to open an investigation and participate in joint investigations with law enforcement officials if the OIG determines that further investigation is warranted.

• SSA's disclosure policy is not always consistently applied, and some field office staff may be confused about the policy.
	• The policy is complex and may lead to inconsistent application, and SSA staff may find it difficult to understand what information can be disclosed.
	• SSA's responsibilities to both assist law enforcement and protect individuals' privacy may exacerbate the confusion and inconsistent application of the agency's policy.

• The Commissioner of SSA has ad hoc authority to disclose information in exceptional cases, but this authority is generally reserved for cases approved on a case-by-case basis.
	• The Commissioner's ad hoc authority is not used frequently, and SSA officials have invoked this authority only 35 times between April 1981 and October 2002.
	• The Commissioner's ad hoc authority is not used to disclose tax return information.

• SSA's disclosure policy is not easily accessible to law enforcement, and some law enforcement officials may be unfamiliar with the process for obtaining information from SSA.
	• SSA's policy is available on its Web site, but it is not easily found and does not

<summary>
• The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) establishes a national policy for managing hazardous waste to minimize threats to human health and the environment.
	• RCRA governs the management of hazardous waste from generation to final disposal.
	• The law contains provisions for identifying and listing hazardous waste, with EPA establishing criteria for classification.

• RCRA's regulations apply to all hazardous waste, regardless of its source or generation method.
	• Waste from both current and past industrial operations is regulated, including remediation waste from cleanups.
	• The requirements apply to any waste identified as hazardous or mixed with hazardous waste.

• RCRA's land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements can create disincentives for cleanups.
	• These requirements can increase costs and time for cleanups, leading parties to choose less aggressive remedies.
	• EPA estimates that exempting contaminated soil from these requirements could reduce treatment costs by nearly 80%.

• The land disposal restrictions and minimum technological requirements can be costly and complex to implement.
	• Treatment to meet these standards may be more stringent than necessary for lightly contaminated media.
	• EPA estimates that exempting relatively low-risk contaminated media could decrease cleanup costs nationwide by 50%.

• The permit process can be time-consuming and costly, with administrative costs ranging from $80,000 to $1 million.
	• The time required to obtain a permit can be extensive, taking 7-9 months for simple units and 5-6 years for more complicated units.
	• Industry representatives estimate that getting a RCRA permit typically takes 5-6 years.

• EPA has issued policy and regulatory alternatives to mitigate the impact of RCRA's requirements on remediation waste.
	• These alternatives include the "contained-in" policy, permit waivers, and the corrective action management unit (CAMU) rule.
	• However, these alternatives have been inconsistently applied and have not solved all the problems.

• Stakeholders disagree on the extent to which waste should be exempt from RCRA's requirements and the states' role in managing remediation waste.
	• Some stakeholders prefer an approach that exempts all remediation waste, while others prefer a more limited exemption.
	• EPA has concluded that comprehensive reform can best be achieved through legislative revision of RCRA.

• EPA's proposed rule, the Hazardous Waste Identification Rule for Contaminated Media (HWIR-Media), aimed to provide a more comprehensive approach to managing remediation waste.
	• However, the proposal was met with significant disagreements and

<summary>
* Medicare program integrity activities were previously subsumed under the general administrative budget, but the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) established the Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) in 1997, providing dedicated funding for program integrity activities.
	* HIPAA stipulated a range of funds available for MIP activities each year, with the maximum amount increasing from $440 million in 1997 to $720 million in 2003.
	* MIP funds are used to support various program integrity activities, including audits, medical reviews, secondary payer activities, benefit integrity, and provider education.

* CMS allocates MIP funds to contractors, including fiscal intermediaries, carriers, Program Safeguard Contractors (PSCs), and Medicare Administrative Contractors (MACs), to perform program integrity activities.
	* Contractors receive MIP funds to perform specific tasks, such as medical reviews, audits, and provider education.
	* CMS also uses MIP funds to support the activities of PSCs, which perform medical reviews and identify potential fraud cases.

* CMS has increased funding for each of its five program integrity activities over the years, but the amount of funding and percentage increase have varied among activities.
	* Provider education received the largest percentage increase in funds, while audit and medical review received the largest amount of funds overall.
	* CMS has also increased its allocation for provider education to address provider concerns about the medical review process.

* CMS officials stated that they generally allocate MIP funds based on historical funding and high-level priorities, but do not consider data or information on the effectiveness of one activity over another.
	* CMS has not routinely collected information to evaluate the comparative effectiveness of its program integrity activities.
	* The agency has not fully assessed whether MIP funds are appropriately allocated within the audit, medical review, benefit integrity, and provider education activities.

* CMS has developed qualitative assessments of the impact of benefit integrity and provider education, but these activities do not lend themselves to quantitative measurement.
	* Benefit integrity contributes to the work of federal law enforcement agencies, and provider education helps reduce billing errors.
	* CMS officials consider these activities to have intangible value, but acknowledge the difficulty in measuring their effectiveness.

* CMS has implemented a revised methodology for calculating the return on investment (ROI) for audit activities, and is developing a component to track the effectiveness of provider education.
	* The agency plans to use this information to evaluate the relative effectiveness of its program integrity activities and make more informed funding decisions.
