<summary>
• TSA has taken steps to enhance screener training, including the development of a dual-function training program that covers both passenger and checked baggage screening.
	• The dual-function training program is modular in design, allowing FSDs to choose whether newly hired screeners receive instruction in one or both screening functions during initial training.
	• The individual modules can also be used to provide recurrent training, such as refreshing checked baggage screening skills for a screener who has worked predominantly as a passenger screener.

• TSA has also implemented an Online Learning Center, which provides screeners with remote access to self-guided training courses.
	• As of September 14, 2004, TSA had provided access to over 550 training courses via the Online Learning Center.
	• The Online Learning Center is available via the Internet and TSA's intranet.

• TSA has established a requirement for screeners to receive 3 hours of recurrent training per week, averaged over a quarter year.
	• One hour is required to be devoted to X-ray image interpretation, and the other 2 hours to screening techniques, review of standard operating procedures, or other mandatory administrative training.
	• TSA has also provided FSDs with additional tools to facilitate and enhance screener training, such as modular bomb sets and weapons training kits.

• TSA has acknowledged that challenges exist in recurrent screener training delivery and is taking steps to address these challenges.
	• TSA is factoring training requirements into workforce planning efforts and distributing training through written materials and CD-ROMs until full Internet/intranet connectivity is achieved.
	• However, TSA does not have a plan for prioritizing and scheduling the deployment of high-speed connectivity to all airport training facilities once funding is available.

• TSA has not established clear policies and procedures for documenting completion of required remedial training.
	• A TSA training bulletin specifies that FSDs must ensure remedial training is provided and a remedial training reporting form is completed and maintained with the screener's local records.
	• However, there is confusion as to how and where these records should be maintained.

• TSA has not established and documented policies and procedures for monitoring completion of basic and recurrent training.
	• TSA headquarters officials stated that they have no formal policy for monitoring screeners' completion of basic training.
	• They also stated that they have neither informal nor formal procedures for monitoring the completion of screeners' recurrent training requirements.

• TSA has implemented a number of improvements designed to enhance screener performance, based on concerns identified in a July

<summary>
* IRS' customer service representatives face challenges in providing effective service due to inadequate training and resources.
	*The training program is broad and complex, covering topics such as tax law and account services.
	*Representatives may not receive refresher training, leading to a lack of proficiency in certain areas.
* IRS has not established a long-term, desired level-of-service goal based on taxpayer needs.
	*The agency's approach to setting goals is inconsistent with federal guidance and industry practices.
	*IRS' goals are based on funding levels rather than customer needs.
* The Operations Center is responsible for forecasting call demand and planning the routing of calls among call sites.
	*The center develops staffing requirements for each call site and monitors site adherence to those requirements.
	*The center also monitors network call traffic status and reroutes calls as necessary.
* IRS faces challenges in recruiting and retaining customer service representatives.
	*Representatives may experience stress and have limited opportunities for advancement.
	*IRS has not established a system for monitoring attrition and identifying its causes.
* The agency is working to improve its recruiting and training processes.
	*IRS is developing a national recruiting strategy and identifying sites where it can target its efforts.
	*The agency is also refocusing its training program to provide just-in-time training.
* IRS' evaluations of its human capital practices do not assess their impact on achieving level-of-service goals.
	*The evaluations focus on making short-term adjustments rather than strategic planning.
	*The agency does not consider how improving practices in one area may affect other areas.
* The Commissioner of Internal Revenue has agreed to establish a long-term, desired service-level goal and work with stakeholders to obtain support and resources.
	*The Commissioner has also agreed to establish a system for assessing competency gaps and meeting refresher training needs.
	*The agency will develop a system for monitoring call center attrition and identifying its causes.
* IRS is working to improve its workload planning and forecasting processes.
	*The agency is adapting an automated system to facilitate forecasting demand and scheduling staff.
	*The system will use historical data to more accurately forecast call demand.
* The agency faces challenges in evaluating its human capital management practices.
	*IRS does not consider how its practices affect its ability to achieve customer service goals.
	*The agency does not assess the interrelationships among its human capital practices.
* The Commissioner has recognized the importance of retaining skilled representatives and is working to identify employees who may be more likely to remain with IRS.

<summary>
• Ginnie Mae's Market Share and Guarantee Volume
	• Ginnie Mae's share of the total MBS market has declined significantly since 1985, from 42% to 7% in 2004.
	• The decline is due to the rapid growth in the conventional MBS market, rather than a significant decline in Ginnie Mae's MBS issuance.
	• Ginnie Mae's outstanding volume of MBS has also declined, falling from $612 billion in 2000 to $453 billion in 2004.

• Ginnie Mae's Products and Initiatives
	• Ginnie Mae has expanded its product offerings, including the introduction of Ginnie Mae II securities, which allow for more flexibility in pooling different types of loans.
	• The agency has also developed a securitization program for hybrid ARM products and has begun guaranteeing securities backed by RHS multifamily loans.
	• Ginnie Mae has also expanded its Targeted Lending Initiative, which provides financial incentives for lenders to increase loan volumes in underserved areas.

• Challenges Facing Ginnie Mae
	• Ginnie Mae faces challenges in responding to changes in the marketplace and meeting the needs of its stakeholders.
	• The agency must also address concerns about its data systems and internal controls, including inconsistencies and inaccuracies in its data.
	• Ginnie Mae must also ensure that its staff have the training, qualifications, and capabilities to oversee contractors and manage the agency's operations.

• Ginnie Mae's Guarantee Fee and Revenue
	• Ginnie Mae charges issuers a guarantee fee, which varies depending on the product, to provide its guarantee of timely payment.
	• The agency's revenue exceeds its expenses, reducing the federal budget deficit.
	• Ginnie Mae's fee income is based on the principal balance of its securities portfolio, so the agency's revenues largely depend on the volume of its outstanding securities.

• Ginnie Mae's Commitment Authority
	• Ginnie Mae's commitment authority is the limit on the total dollar volume of securities that the agency can guarantee.
	• The agency must estimate the amount of commitment authority it will need for future years, based on the actual authority used by the federal guarantee programs it serves.
	• Ginnie Mae has taken steps to improve its estimation process, including carrying over unused authority from prior years.

• Ginnie Mae's Data Systems and Internal Controls
	• Ginnie Mae has faced challenges in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of its data systems.

<summary>
• DOD's Reversal of Illegal and Otherwise Improper Adjustments
	• DOD agreed that $592 million of the $615 million of adjustments should not have been made and has reversed the adjustments.
	• The reversal of the transactions brought to light additional accounting problems that will require detailed reviews to determine the accounting actions necessary to correct the reversed transactions.
	• DOD officials told us they plan to complete all 30 reaudits to correct the fiscal year 2000 illegal and otherwise improper adjustments by September 30, 2002.
	• The reaudits and corrections for fiscal year 2000 closed account adjustments are estimated to take over 21,000 hours to complete.

• DOD's Review of Fiscal Year 2001 Closed Account Adjustments
	• Our evaluation of $291 million of DOD's reported $1.9 billion fiscal year 2001 closed appropriation account adjustments found that $172 million were either illegal or otherwise improper.
	• DOD officials agreed to reverse and correct the $172 million of illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments.
	• The remaining $119 million of the $291 million of adjustments was for adequately documented corrections of errors that DOD had made over the years.
	• DOD officials told us they plan to review another $1.1 billion of fiscal year 2001 closed account adjustments in addition to the $291 million of closed account adjustments that we already reviewed.

• DOD's Implementation of Controls to Prevent Illegal Adjustments
	• DOD began implementing CRS controls to identify and prevent illegal backward adjustments in May 2001.
	• DFAS upgraded CRS to identify and prevent illegal adjustments from moving disbursement charges forward to an appropriation that had not yet been enacted at the time the initial disbursement was made.
	• DOD also changed the CRS default reallocation of adjusting payments from oldest funds first to proration.
	• The changes in contract writing procedures and additional policy requirements should help to reduce errors that require subsequent correcting.

• Causes of Payment Errors and Adjustments
	• Contracts can be assigned anywhere from 1 to over 1,000 ACRNs to accumulate appropriation, budget, and management information.
	• Numerous ACRNs and changes in payment allocations create payment problems by increasing the amount of data that must be entered and opportunities for errors.
	• These problems also lead to costly and extensive contract reconciliations.
	• Simplified contract accounting will be a key element to reform DOD's financial management.

<summary>
• The Internet has grown increasingly important to American businesses and consumers, serving as the host for hundreds of billions of dollars of commerce each year, and is also a critical resource supporting vital services such as power distribution, health care, law enforcement, and national defense.
	• The Internet relies upon a set of functions, called the domain name system, to ensure the uniqueness of each e-mail and Web site address.

• The U.S. government supported the implementation of the domain name system for nearly a decade, largely through a Department of Defense contract, and following a 1997 presidential directive, the Department of Commerce began a process for transitioning the technical responsibility for the domain name system to the private sector.
	• The Department issued a general statement of policy, known as the “White Paper,” which stated that the U.S. government was committed to a transition that would allow the private sector to take leadership for the management of the domain name system.

• ICANN has made significant progress in carrying out MOU tasks related to increasing competition, but progress has been much slower on activities designed to address the other guiding principles: increasing the stability and security of the Internet; ensuring representation of the Internet community in domain name policy-making; and using private, bottom-up coordination.
	• ICANN’s president concluded that ICANN faced serious problems in accomplishing the transition and needed fundamental reform, and proposed a “well-balanced public-private partnership” that involved an increased role for national governments in ICANN.

• The Department is responsible for general oversight of work done under the MOU, as well as the responsibility for determining when ICANN has demonstrated that it has the resources and capability to manage the domain name system.
	• The Department’s public assessment of the status of the transition process has been limited, and it has not issued status reports or publicly commented on specific reform proposals being considered by ICANN.

• The Department sees itself as the responsible steward of the transition, and is responsible for gaining assurance that ICANN has the resources and capability to assume technical management of the Internet domain name system.
	• The Department will be faced with deciding whether the MOU should be extended for a third time, and if so, what amendments to the MOU are needed, or whether some new arrangement with ICANN or some other organization is necessary.

• The effort to privatize the domain name system has reached a critical juncture, as evidenced by slow progress on key tasks and ICANN’s current initiative to reevaluate its mission and consider options for reforming its

<summary>
* The federal government has held funds in trust for Indian tribes since 1820, and the General Allotment Act of 1887 provided for the division of Indian tribal lands into allotments for individual tribal members and families.
	*The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended the allotment of tribal lands and extended the period that the federal government would hold allotted lands in trust.
	*The Secretary of the Interior is required to account for the revenue generated by each interest, invest the trust funds, and provide other trust services to the beneficiaries.
		*The Secretary also is responsible for maintaining official Indian land title and ownership records, managing natural resource assets, and probating estates.
		*Much of this responsibility has been delegated to the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA), which has 12 regional offices and 85 agency offices.
* The Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) was established in 1994 to oversee trust reform efforts.
	*OST has made important progress in implementing trust fund management reforms and plans to complete almost all of the key reforms by November 2007.
	*OST is responsible for trust reforms associated with the trust funds accounting system and the overall integration of the various trust reform automated systems.
* OST has implemented several key trust fund management reforms, including the Trust Funds Accounting System (TFAS) and the Trust Funds Receivable system.
	*TFAS is an accounting and investment system that enables the automated production of account statements for individual Indians and tribal account holders.
	*The Trust Funds Receivable system centralizes the collection of trust payments through a single remittance-processing center.
* OST has also established a Trust Beneficiary Call Center to provide timely responses to beneficiaries' questions and allow them to access account information.
	*The call center was fully operational by December 2005 and has received over 135,000 calls from beneficiaries.
	*The call center has helped to relieve some of the workload from OST and BIA staff in the field.
* The Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) and OST are implementing the Trust Asset and Accounting Management System (TAAMS) to manage land title records and leasing activities for Indian lands.
	*TAAMS is a centralized system with two components: the TAAMS land title system and the leasing module.
	*The TAAMS land title system maintains both current and historical titles, and the leasing module tracks leases of Indian assets.

<summary>
• The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and the Department of Defense (DOD) have been working together to develop a comprehensive, life-long medical record for each service member since 1998.
	• The initial project, Government Computer-Based Patient Record (GCPR), aimed to create an electronic interface to share patient health information between VA and DOD health facilities.
	• The project was later renamed Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) and achieved one-way transfer of data from DOD to VA by 2002.

• The departments are now working towards a two-way exchange of health information through the HealthePeople (Federal) initiative, which includes the development of a common health information architecture and the creation of a virtual medical record.
	• The initiative involves the development of an electronic interface, CHDR, to link the data repositories of VA's HealtheVet VistA and DOD's CHCS II systems.
	• The departments have made progress in developing the CHDR interface, but still face challenges in implementing a project management plan and overcoming data quality issues.</summary>

<summary>
• The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) describes the desired outcome of an income tax audit as the determination of the correct taxable income and tax liability of the person or entity under audit.
	• The auditor has a responsibility to both the audited taxpayer and all other taxpayers to conduct a quality audit.
	• IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality, which address several issues such as the scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management of an audit.

• The primary tool used by IRS to control quality under the nine standards is the review of ongoing audit work by first-line supervisors, called group managers.
	• Group managers are responsible for the quality of audits done by the auditors they manage.
	• They review audit workpapers during the audit to identify problems with audit quality and ensure that the problems are corrected.

• IRS' Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) collects information about the audit process, changes to the process, level of audit quality, and success of any efforts to improve the process and quality.
	• EQMS staff review audit workpapers and assess the degree to which the auditor complied with the audit standards.
	• To pass a standard, the audit must pass all of the key elements.

• The IRM requires that audit workpapers provide the principal support for the auditor's report and document the procedures applied, tests performed, information obtained, and conclusions reached.
	• The five key elements for this workpaper standard involve fully disclosing the audit trail and techniques used, being clear, concise, legible, and organized, and ensuring that tax adjustments recorded in the workpapers agree with IRS Forms 4318 or 4700 and the audit report.
	• The workpapers must also adequately document the audit activity records and appropriately protect taxpayers' rights to privacy and confidentiality.

• The review of IRS audit workpapers found that IRS auditors did not always meet the requirements laid out under this workpaper standard.
	• Tax adjustments shown in the workpapers, summaries, and reports did not agree, and required documents or summaries were not always in the workpaper bundle.
	• Workpapers that were in the bundle were not always legible or complete.

• IRS has historically found problems with the quality of its workpapers, with evaluations conducted as part of IRS' EQMS indicating that IRS auditors met all of the key elements of the workpaper standard in no more than 72 percent of the audits.
	• The success rate indicates whether all of the key elements within the standard were met, and

<summary>
* The Antiterrorism Assistance (ATA) program was authorized by Congress in 1983 to provide training and equipment to friendly countries to deter and counter terrorism.
	*The program's purpose is to enhance the antiterrorism skills of friendly countries, strengthen bilateral ties, and increase respect for human rights.
	*The program offers a wide range of counterterrorism assistance, including training courses and grants of equipment.

* The ATA program is State's largest counterterrorism program, receiving appropriations under the Nonproliferation, Anti-Terrorism, Demining, and Related Programs account.
	*Fiscal year 2002 appropriations for ATA increased to about $158 million, and appropriations have fluctuated since then.
	*The top 10 recipients of ATA allocations represented about 57 percent of ATA funding allocated for training and training-related activities from 2002 to 2007.

* The Coordinator for Counterterrorism is statutorily charged with the overall supervision and coordination of the U.S. government's counterterrorism activities.
	*The Assistant Secretary for Diplomatic Security is responsible for implementing security programs to protect diplomatic personnel and advise chiefs of mission on security matters.
	*Specific roles and responsibilities for S/CT and DS/T/ATA regarding ATA are described in a 1991 internal policy guidance memorandum.

* S/CT and DS/T/ATA did not systematically use country-specific needs assessments and program reviews to plan what types of assistance to provide partner nations.
	*The assessments had weaknesses and inconsistencies, and did not prioritize assistance or include specific timeframes for implementation.
	*DS/T/ATA officials did not consistently use the assessments to determine what types of assistance to provide to partner nations.

* S/CT provides minimal policy guidance to DS/T/ATA, and the guidance does not include suggested country training priorities.
	*DS/T/ATA officials stated that they received little or no guidance from S/CT beyond the tiered list of countries.
	*As a result, neither S/CT nor DS/T/ATA could ensure that program assistance provided to specific countries supports broader U.S. antiterrorism policy goals.

* S/CT and DS/T/ATA did not systematically assess sustainability, and program managers did not consistently include sustainability in ATA planning.
	*Sustainability is the principal intended outcome and focus of program assistance, but State had not developed clear measures and a process for assessing sustainability.

<summary>
* The U.S. bankruptcy system involves multiple federal entities, including bankruptcy courts, the Judicial Conference of the United States, the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts (AOUSC), the Federal Judicial Center, the Department of Justice's U.S. Trustee Program, and the judiciary's Bankruptcy Administrator Program.
	* The U.S. Trustee Program and the Bankruptcy Administrator Program oversee bankruptcy trustees and promote integrity and efficiency in the bankruptcy system.
	* The Federal Judicial Center assists bankruptcy courts with reports and assessments relating to the administration and management of bankruptcy cases.

* The Bankruptcy Code has different chapters for different types of bankruptcy proceedings, including Chapter 7 for liquidation and Chapter 11 for reorganization.
	* Chapter 7 proceedings involve a trustee taking over the assets of the debtor's estate, reducing them to cash, and making distributions to creditors.
	* Chapter 11 proceedings allow debtors to continue some or all of their operations subject to court supervision.

* The resolution of large financial companies is often associated with complex international, legal, and operational challenges.
	* Insolvency laws vary widely across countries, and some countries' legal authorities are not designed to resolve problems in financial groups operating through multiple legal entities that span borders.
	* Regulatory and legal regimes may conflict, and depositor preference, wholesale funding arrangements, derivatives, and repurchase agreements are often treated differently among countries.

* Chapter 15 of the Bankruptcy Code is based on the Model Law on Cross-Border Insolvency of the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL) and aims to promote coordination between courts in different countries during insolvencies.
	* Chapter 15 authorizes several types of coordination, including U.S. case trustees or other authorized entities operating in foreign countries on behalf of a U.S. bankruptcy estate.
	* U.S. courts can communicate information they deem important, coordinate the oversight of debtors' activities, and coordinate proceedings.

* The Dodd-Frank Act amended section 13(3) of the Federal Reserve Act to prohibit the establishment of an emergency lending program or facility for the purpose of assisting a single and specific company to avoid bankruptcy.
	* The Federal Reserve may design emergency lending programs or facilities for the purpose of providing liquidity to the financial system.
	* The authority to make new financial commitments under the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) terminated on October 3, 2010.

* The safe-harbor provisions of the Bankruptcy Code allow counterparties to exercise certain contractual

<summary>
* The electricity industry is composed of four distinct functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations, and is increasingly reliant on computerized technologies, making it susceptible to cyber-based threats.
	*The industry's systems and networks are exposed to potential and known cybersecurity vulnerabilities, including an increased number of entry points and paths that can be exploited.
	*The increased reliance on IT systems and networks also exposes the electric grid to potential and known cybersecurity vulnerabilities.

* Multiple entities have taken steps to help secure the electricity grid, including NERC, NIST, FERC, and the Departments of Homeland Security and Energy.
	*NERC has developed critical infrastructure standards for protecting electric utility–critical and cyber-critical assets, and has enforced compliance with mandatory cybersecurity standards through its Compliance Monitoring and Enforcement Program.
	*NIST has identified cybersecurity standards for smart grid systems and has issued guidelines for securely implementing smart grid systems.

* The Department of Homeland Security has issued recommended practices to reduce risks to industrial control systems in critical infrastructure sectors, including the electricity subsector.
	*The department has also provided on-site support to respond to and analyze security incidents and shared actionable intelligence, vulnerability information, and threat analysis with companies in the electricity subsector.
	*The department has established a program to promote the adoption of the NIST cybersecurity framework.

* The Department of Energy has created sector-specific guidance to assist the sector in implementing the NIST cybersecurity framework.
	*The guidance includes sections that explain framework concepts for its application, identify example resources that may support framework use, provide a general approach to framework implementation, and identify an example of a tool-specific approach to implementing the framework.
	*The department has also been involved in efforts to assist the electricity subsector in the development, assessment, and sharing of cybersecurity standards.

* FERC has taken several actions to address cybersecurity challenges, including evaluating whether cybersecurity challenges should be addressed under the agency's existing cybersecurity authority and efforts.
	*The commission has directed NERC to revise the electricity industry's critical infrastructure protection (CIP) standards to address cybersecurity challenges.
	*The commission has established an Office of Energy Infrastructure Security to help mitigate cybersecurity threats to electricity industry facilities and to improve cybersecurity information sharing.

* Key challenges remain in securing the systems and networks supporting the electricity grid, including monitoring implementation of cybersecurity standards, clarifying regulatory responsibilities, and taking a comprehensive approach to cybersecurity.
	*Experts have expressed concern that there is a lack of clarity about the division of responsibility between federal and state regulators, particularly regarding cybersecurity.

<summary>
• The federal workforce faces significant challenges, including skills gaps and an outdated compensation system.
	• The federal government's pay system does not align well with modern compensation principles, where pay decisions are based on the skills, knowledge, and performance of employees as well as the local labor market.
	• The GS classification system has not kept pace with the government's evolving requirements, and changes to the current system have been few due to the difficulty in finding an optimal mix of attributes that is acceptable to all stakeholders.
	• The federal workforce is on average more highly educated than the private sector workforce, with a higher proportion of federal jobs in skilled occupations such as science, engineering, and program management.
	• The composition of the federal workforce has changed over the past 30 years, with the need for clerical and blue collar roles diminishing and professional, administrative, and technical roles increasing.

• Agencies face challenges in addressing poor performance, including the need for effective performance management systems and meaningful distinctions in employee performance levels.
	• Supervisors play a key role in performance management, and agencies should promote people into supervisory positions based on their supervisory skills and provide sufficient training in performance management.
	• Probationary periods for new employees provide an opportunity for supervisors to evaluate performance, but some supervisors may not use this time effectively due to lack of notification or insufficient time to observe performance.
	• A cultural shift may be needed to acknowledge that a rating of "fully successful" is already a high bar and should be valued and rewarded.
	• Agencies should establish clear accountability for efforts to improve employee engagement and develop a modern, credible employee performance management system.

• The human resources specialist occupation is one of six government-wide, mission-critical skills gap areas identified by OPM.
	• Capacity shortfalls in an agency's personnel office can adversely impact an organization's mission, as seen in the recruitment and retention challenges faced by the Veterans Health Administration.
	• OPM has taken steps to improve the capacity of human resource specialists, including increasing registration in its Human Resources University and validating career path guides.
	• Agencies should prioritize strategic human capital management activities such as talent management, workforce planning, and promoting high performance and a results-oriented culture.
	• Agency leaders should understand the potential for strategic human capital management and elevate the role of the human capital office to better support an agency's operations and mission.

• The federal government faces long-term fiscal challenges, and agencies must identify options to meet their missions with fewer resources.

* The Department of Defense (DOD) received about $52.4 billion and $62.1 billion in supplemental appropriations for the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT) in fiscal years 2004 and 2005, respectively.
	*These funds were primarily used for military personnel and operation and maintenance expenses.
	*The funds were allocated to the Army, Air Force, Navy, and Marine Corps through various appropriation accounts.

* The DOD also received additional funds through its annual appropriations, totaling about $7.9 billion in fiscal year 2004 and $7.6 billion in fiscal year 2005.
	*These funds were intended to support GWOT, but the DOD lost visibility over how they were used.
	*The funds were allocated to the military services' various appropriation accounts, but there is no documentation on how they were expended.

* The DOD used various authorities to cover gaps between supplemental appropriations and reported obligations for GWOT, including transferring funds and reducing or deferring planned spending for peacetime operations.
	*These actions affected the DOD's peacetime operations and may create spending pressures in future years.
	*The DOD did not explicitly take into account the additional funds provided through its annual appropriations when considering funding for GWOT.

* The military services reported obligations in support of GWOT that were above the supplemental funds appropriated by the Congress in fiscal year 2004.
	*The DOD used authorities granted to it to cover the gaps, including transferring funds and reducing or deferring planned spending for peacetime operations.
	*The military services absorbed the remaining gaps by reducing or deferring spending in noncritical areas.

* The Army, Air Force, and Navy received additional funds in their annual appropriations, totaling about $7.9 billion in fiscal year 2004 and $7.6 billion in fiscal year 2005.
	*These funds were intended to support GWOT, but the DOD lost visibility over how they were used.
	*The funds were allocated to the military services' various appropriation accounts, but there is no documentation on how they were expended.

* The DOD's accounting systems do not separately identify the portion of the department's annual appropriations that were described as having been requested to support GWOT.

* The Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) was extended by the Department of the Treasury (Treasury) to address ongoing weaknesses in the economy, particularly in the housing market and small business lending.
	*The extension was made to retain resources to respond to financial instability and to provide flexibility to modify the Making Home Affordable (MHA) program.
	*The decision to extend TARP was made in coordination with relevant policymakers, including the Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC).

* The MHA program was extended to address continued weaknesses in the housing market, including high foreclosure rates and mortgage delinquencies.
	*The program was modified to allow more borrowers to qualify for modification, including those with Federal Housing Administration (FHA) loans and those who owe more than the current value of their home.
	*Treasury plans to track performance measures, including the number of HAMP modifications and the redefault rate, to evaluate the program's effectiveness.

* The small business lending program was allocated new resources to support lending to creditworthy small businesses.
	*Treasury has yet to set explicit objectives for its small business lending programs, but has identified indicators of small business credit conditions, including the Federal Reserve's Senior Loan Officer Opinion Survey (SLOOS) and the National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) survey.
	*The program aims to provide capital to small banks and improve access to credit for small businesses.

* The bank capital programs, including the Capital Purchase Program (CPP) and the Capital Assistance Program (CAP), were ended due to banks' renewed ability to access private capital markets.
	*The CPP was successful in increasing lending to U.S. businesses and consumers, with banks raising over $200 billion in private capital.
	*The CAP was not needed as banks were able to raise capital from private sources.

* The Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility (TALF) was not extended due to improvements in the asset-backed securitization markets.
	*The program was successful in increasing liquidity and reopening the markets, with spreads tightening significantly from their heights in 2009.
	*The program's expiration was justified by declining asset spreads in the ABS market.

* The Public-Private Investment Program (PPIP) was not extended due to improvements in the prices of legacy assets.
	*The program was successful in allowing financial institutions to repair their balance sheets by removing troubled assets.

* The Federal Meat Inspection Act, the Poultry Products Inspection Act, and the Egg Products Inspection Act give the USDA's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) the authority to ensure the safety of meat, poultry, and certain egg products.
	* FSIS works to ensure the safety of food products processed in the United States through a regulatory system of preventive controls that identifies hazards early in the production process to minimize the risk of contamination.

* The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and the Public Health Service Act give the FDA the authority to ensure the safety of all other foods, including fruits and vegetables, dairy products, seafood, and certain canned, frozen, and packaged foods.
	* FDA works to ensure the safety of food products processed in the United States through a regulatory system of preventive controls that identifies hazards early in the production process to minimize the risk of contamination.

* The food-processing sector is generally described as the middle segment of the farm-to-table continuum, extending from the time livestock and crops leave the farm for slaughter and processing into food until it reaches retail establishments.
	* FDA and FSIS work to ensure the safety of food products processed in the United States through a regulatory system of preventive controls that identifies hazards early in the production process to minimize the risk of contamination.

* FDA and FSIS have issued guidelines to the food-processing industry suggesting measures to enhance security at their facilities, including conducting a risk assessment, developing a plan to address security risks at plants, and adopting a wide range of security measures inside and outside the premises.
	* Food-processing facilities are not required to adopt any of the security measures but are encouraged to adopt those that they feel are best suited for their operations.

* FDA and FSIS lack comprehensive information on the extent to which food-processing companies are adopting security measures, and they do not collect information on industry's voluntary implementation of security measures.
	* The agencies are, therefore, unable to determine the extent to which food processors have voluntarily implemented such measures.

* The Congress directed medium-size and large-size community water systems to assess their vulnerability to terrorist attacks and to develop an emergency response plan to prepare for such an event.
	* The act also authorized funding to be used for basic security enhancements, such as the installation of fencing, gating, lighting, or security cameras.

* FDA and FSIS have different levels of "satisfaction" with or "confidence" in the efforts of the processing facilities they inspect to ensure the protection of food from acts of deliberate contamination.

<summary>
* The largest interagency contracting vehicle is the MAS program, also known as the Federal Supply Schedule or the schedules program, which is directed and managed by GSA.
	* The MAS program provides advantages to both federal agencies and vendors, including simplified procurement methods and wider exposure for commercial products.

* Government buyers usually pay a fee for using other agencies' GWACs, MACs, and schedule contracts, which are typically a percentage of the procurement value.
	* These fees are paid to the sponsoring agency and are expected to cover the costs of administering the contract.

* Enterprisewide contracts are similar to interagency contracts but generally do not allow purchases from the contract outside of the original acquiring activity.
	* Enterprisewide contracting programs can be used to reduce contracting administrative overhead, provide information on agency spending, and avoid fees charged for using interagency contracts.

* In fiscal year 2008, federal agencies spent at least $60 billion through GWACs, MACs, the MAS program, and enterprisewide contracts.
	* The majority of this spending, about $46.8 billion, was through the MAS program.

* The total amount of money spent using enterprisewide contracting programs is approaching the amount spent for GWACs.
	* Numerous agencies are planning to increase their use of enterprisewide contracts to address the administration's goal of reducing contract spending by 7 percent.

* OMB and agencies lack reliable and comprehensive data to effectively leverage, manage, and oversee interagency and enterprisewide contracts.
	* The federal government's official procurement database is not sufficient or reliable for identifying these contracts.

* Concerns remain about contract duplication, with vendors and agency officials expressing concerns about duplication of effort among contracts.
	* This duplication could result in increased costs to both the vendor and the government, and missed opportunities to leverage the government's buying power.

* Limited governmentwide policy is in place for establishing and overseeing MACs and enterprisewide contracts.
	* Recent legislation and OFPP initiatives are expected to strengthen oversight and management of MACs, but no similar initiatives are underway to strengthen oversight of enterprisewide contracts.

* GSA faces challenges in effectively managing the MAS program, including a lack of transactional data and limited use of pricing tools.
	* GSA has initiated a process improvement initiative to collect more transactional data, but this initiative is currently in its early stages.

* The decentralized management structure for the MAS program and shortcomings

<summary>
* The General Services Administration's (GSA) 18F and the Office of Management and Budget's (OMB) United States Digital Service (USDS) were established to improve the federal government's information technology (IT) efforts.
	* Both 18F and USDS have provided a variety of development and consulting services to agencies to support their technology efforts, including custom software solutions, acquisition services, and training.

* 18F and USDS have developed procedures for prioritizing projects, but have not fully implemented important program management practices, such as defining outcome-oriented goals and measuring performance.
	* For example, 18F has developed several outcome-oriented goals and performance measures, but not all of its goals are outcome-oriented, and it has not yet measured program performance.

* The majority of agencies that partnered with 18F and USDS were satisfied with the services provided, citing factors such as delivering quality products and services, providing good customer service, and employing staff with valuable knowledge and skills.
	* However, some agencies expressed dissatisfaction with services provided by 18F, citing poor customer service, higher than expected costs, and concerns about the use of open source code.

* OMB has called for agencies to establish digital service teams, but USDS policy does not require agencies to define the expected responsibilities and authorities governing the relationships between Chief Information Officers (CIOs) and digital service teams.
	* As a result, agency CIOs may not be effectively involved in the digital service teams, which is inconsistent with long-standing law and OMB guidance on CIO responsibilities.

* To address these issues, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) has made recommendations to GSA and OMB, including ensuring that goals and associated performance measures are outcome-oriented, assessing actual results for each performance measure, and updating USDS policy to clearly define the responsibilities and authorities governing the relationships between CIOs and digital service teams.
	* Implementing these recommendations will help GSA and OMB effectively measure performance, prioritize resources, and ensure that CIOs play an integral role in agency digital service teams.
</summary>

<summary>
* The baby boom generation is aging, and this demographic shift will lead to significant changes in the ratio of working-age population to those aged 65 or older.
	*The aged dependency ratio is expected to rise from 21% in 2000 to 35% by 2030.
	*This increase is due to the growing number of older persons and the slowing growth of the labor force of younger workers.

* The labor force growth rate for workers under 55 has slowed down from 1.9% between 1950-1990 to 0.3% between 2000-2025.
	*This slowdown is expected to continue, leading to a shortage of skilled workers.
	*Employers will need to rely more heavily on older workers to maintain productivity and economic growth.

* Social Security retirement policy changes aim to strengthen incentives for older workers to continue working.
	*The elimination of benefit reductions for beneficiaries who work and have reached the normal retirement age is one such change.
	*The delayed retirement credit for persons who claim benefits after the normal retirement age is also being increased.

* The Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) promotes the employment of older persons based on their ability rather than age.
	*ADEA prohibits age discrimination in employment and applies to firms with 20 or more employees.
	*Some states have their own laws protecting older workers in small businesses.

* Pension laws and regulations can influence the work decisions of older individuals.
	*Many pension plans have features that encourage employees to retire at or before age 65.
	*The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) administers policies on pension distributions to ensure equitable distribution and security of pension benefits.

* The number of older workers will grow substantially over the next two decades.
	*According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), the number of older labor force participants will increase from 18.4 million in 2000 to 31.8 million in 2015.
	*Older workers will become a larger percentage of all workers, from 13% in 2000 to 20% in 2015.

* Older workers are employed in a diverse group of occupations, but are a growing proportion of white-collar occupations.
	*The proportion of workers aged 55-74 in managerial/administrative and professional/technical occupations will increase by 2.9% and 1.6%, respectively, between 2000 and 2008.
	*The composition of the older workforce will shift

<summary>
* The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) was created in 1986 to facilitate legitimate travel of visitors for business or tourism, and it was permanently established in 2000.
	*The program allows for visa-free travel to the United States, boosting international business and tourism, and creating economic benefits.
	*It also enables the State Department to allocate more resources to visa-issuing posts in countries with higher risk applicant pools.

* The Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) was implemented in 2008 to assess passengers' eligibility to travel to the United States under the VWP.
	*ESTA requires passengers to provide biographical information and answer eligibility questions, and it has reduced the average time to process VWP passengers by 17.8 to 54 percent.
	*However, DHS has not fully analyzed the potential risks posed by cases where carriers boarded passengers for VWP travel without verifying that they had ESTA approval.

* The 9/11 Act requires VWP countries to enter into agreements with the United States to share information on lost and stolen passports and to report whether citizens and nationals of that country traveling to the United States represent a threat to U.S. security or welfare.
	*As of January 2011, 19 of the 36 VWP countries had signed Homeland Security Presidential Directive 6 (HSPD-6) agreements, and 13 had begun sharing information according to the signed agreements.
	*However, many VWP countries have not entered into all required agreements, and some have not implemented the agreements they have signed.

* DHS conducts biennial reviews of VWP countries to evaluate their continued participation in the program, but it has not completed half of the mandated reports in a timely manner.
	*The reviews examine counterterrorism and law enforcement capabilities, border control and immigration programs and policies, and security procedures.
	*However, DHS has not consistently submitted the reports in a timely manner since the legal requirement was imposed in 2002.

* To ensure that DHS can identify and mitigate potential security risks associated with the VWP, the GAO recommends that the Secretary of Homeland Security establish time frames for the regular review and documentation of cases of VWP passengers traveling to a U.S. port of entry without verified ESTA approval.
	*The GAO also recommends that DHS take steps to address delays in the biennial country review process so that the mandated country reports can be completed on time.
	*These actions will help to ensure that the VWP is implemented in

<summary>
• State child welfare systems face challenges in keeping pace with growing caseloads, with the foster care population increasing from 276,000 in 1984 to 494,000 in 1995.
	• The federal government plays a crucial role in financing foster care and establishing minimum procedural requirements for the placement process.
	• The Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act of 1980 requires states to make reasonable efforts to prevent or eliminate the need for removing children from their homes.

• States have implemented various initiatives to expedite and improve the permanency process, including concurrent planning and expediting the termination of parental rights.
	• Concurrent planning involves working towards reuniting a family while developing an alternate plan for permanently removing the child if reunification efforts fail.
	• Some states have reported success with concurrent planning, such as Colorado, which saw 87% of children achieve permanent placement within 1 year.

• The court system plays a critical role in achieving permanency, with some states revising court procedures to expedite case processing.
	• Hamilton County, Ohio, implemented new procedures, including designating lawyers as magistrates to hear cases and assigning one magistrate to each case for continuity.
	• These changes resulted in cost savings and improved outcomes, such as a decrease in the number of children placed in four or more different foster care placements.

• States have also implemented low-cost, creative methods for financing and providing services to address specific barriers to reuniting families.
	• Arizona's Housing Assistance Program focused on families with inadequate housing and resulted in 939 children being reunited with their families between 1991 and 1995.
	• The program also saved the state over $1 million in foster care-related costs.

• The lack of evaluation data hinders the ability to assess the overall impact of these initiatives.
	• Many states did not conduct systematic evaluations of their programs, and outcome information was often limited to state reports and observations.
	• The availability of evaluation information would help identify unintended outcomes and inform future initiatives.

• Key factors are necessary for successfully developing and implementing initiatives, including long-term involvement of officials, stakeholder involvement, and resources.
	• States must also address the difficult issues of deciding when to pursue reunification and when to seek the termination of parental rights.
	• Initiatives must be tailored to the specific needs of each state and its child welfare system.

• The rise in foster care caseloads is expected to continue, placing pressure on states to develop initiatives to move children into permanent homes more quickly.

<summary>
* The DATA Act aims to improve the transparency of federal spending by requiring agencies to report their expenditures and link spending information to federal program activities.
	*The act requires government-wide reporting on a variety of federal funds, including budget and financial information, and tracking of these funds at multiple points in the federal spending lifecycle.
	*The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Department of the Treasury are responsible for leading the implementation of the act, and have taken steps to help agencies meet their reporting requirements.

* Agencies face challenges in implementing the DATA Act, including issues with internal controls over financial reporting, financial management systems, and information technology security and controls.
	*These challenges may affect the quality of data submitted by agencies, and increase the risk of incomplete, inaccurate, or untimely data.
	*The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has identified material weaknesses and significant deficiencies in agencies' financial audits and readiness reviews, which may impact the quality of data reported under the DATA Act.

* To address these challenges, OMB and Treasury have taken steps to improve data governance and provide additional guidance to agencies, including the establishment of a Data Standards Committee and the release of policy guidance on reporting requirements.
	*However, more work is needed to ensure the effective implementation of the DATA Act, including the development of a robust data governance framework and the provision of clear policies and procedures for developing and maintaining data standards.
	*The GAO has made recommendations to OMB and Treasury to address these challenges and improve the implementation of the DATA Act.</summary>

<summary>
  • The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) has an agreement with the Acquisition Services Directorate (ARC) to provide contracting support for a fee. However, in contracting with MPRI for an organizational assessment, several required steps were not taken, including competition among Schedule vendors and a convincing demonstration of why a sole-source order was necessary.
	• The determination of the reasonableness of MPRI's price was not properly documented, and OSC officials performed duties normally done by contracting officer's representatives without authorization or training.
	• The sole-source justification listed other factors, including insufficient time and budget constraints, but these were not valid rationales for a sole-source order.

  • The OSC's primary mission is to protect federal employees from prohibited personnel practices, but the agency's employees do not have an external, independent agency to represent them in addressing allegations of prohibited personnel practices.
	• The MSPB and EEOC have taken steps to address potential conflicts of interest when their own employees use their agencies' respective redress processes, but OSC would need explicit authority to implement similar options.
	• Potential options for OSC employees include an external investigation through an independent entity, expanded rights to appeal directly to MSPB, or an independent agency to represent them in addressing allegations of prohibited personnel practices.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) faces challenges in key areas, including the development of new systems, modernization of existing systems, and increasing interoperability with the Department of Defense (DOD).
	• The VA operates approximately 240 information systems, manages 314,000 desktop computers and 30,000 laptops, and administers nearly 460,000 network user accounts for employees and contractors.
	• The department has an initiative underway to modernize its electronic health record system, known as VistA, and to establish interoperability with DOD's system.
	• The VA has requested appropriations to make improvements in several areas, including veterans' access to health care, benefits, and services.

• The VA's IT infrastructure is critical to the department's efforts to provide benefits and services to veterans, but it faces challenges in maintaining and modernizing its systems.
	• The department has identified several legacy systems that are in need of modernization or replacement, including the Personnel and Accounting Integrated Data (PAID) system and the Benefits Delivery Network (BDN) system.
	• The VA has plans to replace PAID and BDN, but the timeline for these efforts is uncertain.
	• The department has also initiated an effort to transform the focus and functions of the Office of Information and Technology (OI&T).

• The VA's efforts to achieve electronic health record interoperability with DOD have been ongoing, but the department still faces challenges in this area.
	• The VA and DOD have engaged in several near-term efforts to expand interoperability between their existing electronic health record systems.
	• The departments have also moved forward with plans to modernize their respective electronic health record systems.
	• However, the VA has not identified outcome-oriented goals and metrics to measure the success of its interoperability efforts.

• The VA's Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA) has made progress in developing and implementing the Veterans Benefits Management System (VBMS), but the system still has limitations.
	• The VBMS is not able to fully support disability and pension claims, as well as appeals processing.
	• The system's development has been delayed, and the VBA has not produced a plan that identifies when the system will be completed.
	• The VBA has also not conducted a customer satisfaction survey to assess user satisfaction with the system.
</summary>

<summary>
* HCFA's Unique Authority and Responsibility
	*HCFA serves about 33 million beneficiaries and processes an estimated 900 million claims in fiscal year 1997.
	*HCFA is responsible for paying and monitoring more than 400 managed care health plans that serve more than 5 million beneficiaries.
	*The Medicare statute divides benefits into two parts: hospital insurance (part A) and supplementary medical insurance (part B).
	*Part A covers inpatient hospital, skilled nursing facility, hospice, and certain home health care services.

* HCFA's Workforce and Contractors
	*HCFA has slightly less than 4,000 full-time employees, with 65% working in the agency's headquarters offices.
	*The rest of the employees work in the agency's 10 regional offices across the country.
	*HCFA oversees more than 60 claims processing contractors that employ an estimated 22,200 people.
	*These contractors perform Medicare claims processing and review functions.

* Recent Legislation and Reforms
	*The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) provides the opportunity to enhance Medicare's anti-fraud-and-abuse activities.
	*The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 (BBA) introduces new health plan options and major payment reforms.
	*BBA provides for a dramatic expansion of health plan choices available to Medicare beneficiaries.
	*BBA makes reforms to payment methods in traditional fee-for-service Medicare and managed care.

* Challenges in Implementing Reforms
	*HCFA is rethinking its strategy to develop, modernize, or otherwise improve the agency's multiple automated claims processing and other information systems.
	*HCFA plans to make changes as an interim measure until comprehensive reengineering can take place.
	*HCFA is confronting transition problems resulting from the recent loss of large-volume claims processing contractors.
	*HCFA is experiencing disruptions common to organizational transitions.

* Distribution of Agency Resources
	*Managers are concerned that the quality of other work might be compromised or tasks might be neglected altogether.
	*Managers noted that some BBA-related tasks are completely new and add to the workload.
	*Managers also noted that others merely formalize work that was already underway but impose deadlines for completion.
	*Managers expressed concerns about the staff's mix and level of skills.

* Need for Specialized Expertise
	*Managers identified the need for staff with specialized technical expertise, such as computer system analysts and survey statisticians.

<summary>
* FAA Funding Structure
	*The current funding structure is based on excise taxes and General Fund contributions.
	*The Trust Fund provides 82% of FAA's funding, with revenues from excise taxes on airline tickets, aviation fuel, and cargo shipments.
	*The General Fund contributes 18% of FAA's funding, with the amount varying from year to year.
	*The Trust Fund was established by the Airport and Airway Revenue Act of 1970 to fund the development of a nationwide airport and airway system.

* Proposed Changes to FAA Funding
	*The administration's reauthorization proposal would change FAA's financing system to one based more on cost-based charges.
	*Funding for ATO would come primarily from user charges on commercial aircraft and fuel taxes on general aviation aircraft.
	*Contributions from the General Fund would be appropriated to FAA to cover ATO costs of providing services to military and other public aircraft.
	*The proposal would also create an advisory board and give FAA limited borrowing authority.

* Cost Allocation Methodology
	*FAA's new cost allocation study divides NAS users into two groups: high-performance aircraft and piston aircraft.
	*The study assigns costs to users based on the assumption that high-performance users generally compete for the same air traffic control resources.
	*The study does not conduct a statistical cost analysis to determine whether high-performance aircraft of different types might impose sufficiently different costs on the system.
	*The study's methodology has raised concerns among industry stakeholders and requires further analysis.

* Concerns with Current Funding Structure
	*FAA has expressed concern that revenues from the current funding structure depend heavily on factors not connected to FAA's workload and costs.
	*The current structure raises concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency.
	*The administration's proposal is intended to address these concerns by linking FAA's revenues more closely with its costs.
	*The proposal would eliminate all excise taxes except the taxes on fuel and the tax on arriving and departing international passengers.

* Funding for AIP
	*The administration's proposal would fund AIP through a fuel tax of 13.6 cents per gallon on commercial and general aviation operators.
	*The proposal would also impose a tax of $6.39 per passenger on the use of international travel facilities.
	*The decision to establish equal tax rates for commercial and general aviation operators was made to achieve fairness and simplicity.
	*However, this approach may raise equity issues, as commercial aviation users would be paying for

<summary>
* The General Services Administration (GSA) is planning its FTS Networx acquisition program, which includes awarding new governmentwide contracts for long distance and international voice and data communications services, wireless services, and satellite telecommunications services.
	*The program has five goals: meet agency needs, obtain best value, encourage strong competition, respond to the changing marketplace, and provide expanded opportunities for small businesses.

* GSA faces significant challenges in finalizing its program strategy, including ensuring adequate inventory information, establishing measures of success, structuring and scheduling the Networx contracts, and initiating implementation planning actions.
	*GSA has not yet established a comprehensive set of performance measures for the Networx acquisition program, and it is unclear whether GSA and federal agencies have established accurate inventories of existing telecommunications services.</summary>

<summary>
• FSA's Performance Plan and Progress
	• FSA's performance plan discusses its three strategic goals: increasing customer and employee satisfaction while decreasing unit cost.
	• The plan includes measures for gauging FSA progress in meeting each of these strategic goals.
	• FSA uses the American Customer Satisfaction Index (ACSI) and the Gallup Q12 to measure customer and employee satisfaction.
	• FSA's scores on both the ACSI and Gallup Q12 increased from fiscal year 1999 through fiscal year 2001.

• FSA's Unit Cost Calculation
	• FSA's unit cost calculation has some limitations, as it does not measure costs per se.
	• The calculation does not include obligations FSA sees as beyond its control, such as obligations for services shared with the department.
	• FSA's current calculation is a change from the way it calculated unit cost in the past, making it difficult to compare unit cost across years.
	• FSA officials believe the unit cost measure is a useful tool for internal management information purposes.

• FSA's Systems Integration Efforts
	• FSA has devised an enterprise-wide systems architecture to integrate its many, disparate information systems.
	• FSA has recently initiated a new approach, commonly referred to as middleware, to provide users with a more complete and integrated view of information.
	• FSA's implementation of the middleware technology remains in its early stages.
	• FSA needs to properly implement and manage its strategy to ameliorate its longstanding database integration problems.

• FSA's Program Integrity Efforts
	• FSA works to ensure program integrity in many ways, including providing technical assistance to schools and collecting on defaulted loans.
	• FSA's draft fiscal year 2002 performance plan reflects its increasing reliance on providing technical assistance to schools.
	• FSA has developed strategies intended to improve schools' regulatory compliance, but it is not clear how FSA will know whether its strategies are effective.
	• FSA needs to develop an indicator of schools' compliance and define success for its strategies.

• FSA's Human Capital Management
	• FSA has taken steps to develop its human capital, but gaps remain in its overall human capital approach.
	• FSA's human capital senior manager has not been an active participant in setting FSA's strategic direction.
	• FSA still faces challenges in planning for the succession, deployment, and training of staff.
	• FSA has not yet implemented a performance management system.
