<summary>
  • Glaucoma is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by the loss of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and optic nerve atrophy, with multiple factors contributing to its progression, including high intraocular pressure (IOP) and low cerebral spinal fluid pressure.
	• Mller cells play a crucial role in retinal function and are involved in pathological retinal diseases such as glaucoma.
	• Reactive Mller cells can aggravate retinal damage by releasing cytokines like tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), which contributes to neurodegeneration in glaucoma.

  • The study investigated the effects of -aminoadipic acid (AAA) on Mller cell gliosis in a rat model of acute ocular hypertension (AOH) mimicking glaucoma.
	• AAA treatment was found to inhibit Mller cell gliosis and protect against retinal abnormalities induced in the AOH model.
	• The study suggests that AAA may be a potential therapeutic target in the treatment of neurodegeneration in glaucoma by attenuating Mller cell gliosis and downregulating TNF-α production.
</summary>

<summary>
* Laparoscopy-assisted endoscopic full-thickness resection with ligation device (LAEFTR-L) is a new technique for treating nonampullary superficial duodenal neoplasms (SDNs).
	*This method combines the benefits of laparoscopic and endoscopic approaches to minimize the risk of severe adverse events (SAEs) and intraperitoneal tumor dissemination.
	*The LAEFTR-L procedure involves the use of a ligation device to mark and ligate the tumor, followed by endoscopic resection and retrieval of the specimen.
* The LAEFTR-L procedure has several advantages over conventional endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) and full-thickness resection (FTR) methods.
	*It allows for complete resection without peritoneal exposure of tumor cells, reducing the risk of intraperitoneal tumor dissemination.
	*The procedure does not require proficient experience in ESD, and the total operative time is comparable to conventional FTR methods.
* The indications for LAEFTR-L include tumor size and location.
	*Lesions smaller than 15 mm in diameter may be candidates for this procedure, and additional studies are needed to evaluate the feasibility of resecting larger lesions.
	*Tumor location is also important, and LAEFTR-L may not be suitable for lesions close to the ampulla of vater due to technical difficulties with laparoscopic mobilization.
* The LAEFTR-L procedure has shown promising results in a small study of 5 patients, with complete resection achieved in all cases and no severe adverse events reported.
	*However, prospective studies are needed to further evaluate the efficacy and safety of LAEFTR-L procedures.
	*Long-term outcomes of patients undergoing LAEFTR-L need to be investigated to determine the risk of intraperitoneal tumor dissemination and other potential complications.
</summary>

<summary>
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of autosomal recessive conditions caused by defects in various enzymes necessary for cortisol synthesis.
	• 90-95% of CAH cases are caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency (21-OHD).
	• CAH is classified into classic (severe) and non-classic (mild or late-onset) forms.

• Classic CAH is subclassified into salt-losing and non-salt-losing (simple virilizing) forms.
	• Salt-losing CAH is a severe form with a concurrent defect in aldosterone biosynthesis.
	• Non-salt-losing CAH may be asymptomatic or associated with signs of androgen excess.

• The pathophysiology of CAH due to 21-OHD is closely linked to the degree of enzyme deficiency.
	• A defect in cortisol biosynthesis leads to a compensatory increase in hypothalamic and pituitary secretion of CRH and ACTH.
	• This stimulates the adrenal cortex and results in hyperplastic adrenal glands.

• CAH can be diagnosed in newborn screening programs by screening for 17-hydroxyprogesterone in dried blood spots.
	• A high concentration of 17-hydroxyprogesterone in a randomly timed blood sample is diagnostic of classic 21-OHD.
	• The gold standard for diagnosis is a corticotropin stimulation test.

• The aim of medical treatment in 21-OHD is to suppress adrenal androgens sufficiently without impairing growth.
	• Glucocorticoids are given in doses sufficient to suppress excessive secretion of CRH and ACTH.
	• Fludrocortisone is administered in cases of salt-losing manifestation and elevated plasma renin activity.

• Infants with the salt-losing form of 21-OHD require mineralocorticoid and sodium chloride supplements in addition to glucocorticoid treatment.
	• Treatment is indicated only for those with symptoms and aims to reduce hyperandrogenism.
	• The use of fludrocortisone in patients with non-salt-losing classic CAH allows management with lower doses of glucocorticoid.

• The development of adrenal adenoma or carcinoma in patients with CAH is rare, but the incidence of adrenal masses appears to be higher in CAH patients.
	• Histological types of adrenal tumor include adenoma, myelolipoma, and hemangioma.
	• Chronic poor compliance

<summary>
* Modifiable lifestyle behaviors known to reduce cardiovascular disease risk were associated with poor/fair self-rated health (SRH) in males and females.
	*Low fruits and vegetables intake was associated with poor/fair SRH in both males and females.
	*High fat intake was also associated with poor/fair SRH in both males and females.
	*The study found significant differences in ethnicity for SRH, with ethnic differences adjusted in the final models.
	*The study's findings have implications for designing and monitoring lifestyle interventions to prevent cardiovascular diseases.

* Poorer SRH was significantly associated with low physical activity in females only.
	*Females who engaged in less physical activity were more likely to report poor/fair SRH as compared to those who were more physically active.
	*The association between physical activity and SRH was not significant for males once adjustment variables were added.
	*The study's findings on gender differences in physical activity levels and SRH are in agreement with several other studies.
	*The gradient effect of the levels of physical activity on SRH was demonstrated by evidence from several past studies.

* The study's results have implications for public health interventions and policy-making.
	*The study highlights the importance of promoting healthy lifestyle behaviors, such as a balanced diet and regular physical activity, to prevent cardiovascular diseases.
	*The study's findings suggest that gender differences should be taken into account when designing and implementing lifestyle interventions.
	*The study's results can inform policy-making and public health interventions aimed at reducing cardiovascular disease risk.
	*The study's findings have implications for healthcare providers and practitioners working with diverse patient populations.</summary>

  * The role of endoscopic injection of dextranomer/hyaluronic acid copolymer (DX/HA) has expanded as a treatment option for vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), offering a minimally invasive alternative to open surgery with a success rate of 75-80%.
	*The success rate of DX/HA injections can be influenced by various factors, including the technique used, the grade of VUR, and the presence of lower tract anomalies.
  * The use of positional instillation of contrast (PIC) cystography can detect occult VUR and prevent postoperative contralateral new onset of VUR in patients treated with unilateral VUR.
	*PIC cystography can also be used intraoperatively to evaluate the success of DX/HA injection, but its correlation with postoperative voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is only 80%, indicating that postoperative studies cannot be replaced by intraoperative cystograms.

	*Dependence on sonographer expertise
	*Limitations due to descent of fetal head and progressive ossification of skull bones
	*Maternal obesity and oligohydramnios affecting sensitivity

	*Increasing role due to advances in MRI technology and knowledge of fetal pathology
	*Addressing the additional role of MRI in diagnosing and characterizing fetal anomalies

* Definition and Classification of Ventriculomegaly
	*Descriptive term used when maximal diameter of atrium of lateral ventricles exceeds 10 mm
	*Classification into mild (10-12 mm), moderate (12-15 mm), and severe (>15 mm)
	*Alternative classification system based on measuring thickness of overlying brain parenchyma

* Causes of Ventriculomegaly
	*Imbalance between production and absorption of cerebrospinal fluid
	*Abnormal cerebral development, such as partial or complete agenesis of corpus callosum
	*Destructive disease processes leading to loss of neuronal tissue

* Incidence of Additional Anomalies
	*Reported incidence up to 70-85%
	*Dependence on number of fetuses included in study and distribution of severity
	*Term "isolated ventriculomegaly" used when no other structural anomalies are seen

* Fetal MRI Techniques
	*HASTE sequence most commonly used
	*T1-weighted imaging used to detect hemorrhages or calcifications
	*Novel scanning sequences include diffusion-weighted imaging and diffusion tensor imaging

* Limitations of Fetal MRI
	*Impact of fetal motion on image acquisition
	*Relatively low spatial resolution compared to ultrasound
	*Contraindications similar to those for non-pregnant patients

* Added Value of MRI in Detecting Additional Anomalies
	*Detection and characterization of additional cerebral anomalies
	*Importance of accurate characterization for prognosis and parental counseling

	*Detection of cortical malformations, such as polymicrogyria
	*Assessment of normal and pathological cortical

<summary>
* Lung cancer is the third most common cancer diagnosed and the leading cause of cancer-related death in the US.
	*According to the American Cancer Society, an estimated 226,160 patients were diagnosed with lung cancer and 160,340 died from the disease in 2012.

* Bone metastasis is a common complication of lung cancer, occurring in approximately 30-40% of patients with distant metastatic disease.
	*Bone metastasis can lead to skeletal-related events (SREs) such as pathological fractures, spinal cord compression, and severe pain.

* A study of 126,123 patients with lung cancer found that 19.8% had evidence of bone metastasis, and 51% of these patients experienced SREs.
	*The most common SRE was radiotherapy to bone, followed by fracture, spinal cord compression, and surgery to bone.

* The study found that having a bone metastasis was associated with increased mortality among lung cancer patients.
	*The association was similar for bone metastasis complicated by SRE and for bone metastasis without SRE.

* The study used data from the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program and Medicare claims to identify patients with lung cancer and bone metastasis.
	*The study included patients aged 65 years or older who were diagnosed with lung cancer between 1999 and 2005.

* The study found that the proportion of patients with bone metastasis varied by stage at diagnosis, with 38% of patients with distant stage lung cancer having bone metastasis within a year of diagnosis.
	*The study also found that the proportion of patients with bone metastasis was similar for men and women, and for white and African American patients.

* The study had several limitations, including the use of claims data to identify bone metastasis and the exclusion of patients under the age of 65.
	*The study also did not include information on functional status or treatment factors that may have affected outcomes.

* The study concluded that having a bone metastasis is associated with increased mortality among patients with lung cancer, and that SREs are common among patients with bone metastasis.
	*The study highlights the importance of early detection and treatment of bone metastasis in patients with lung cancer.
</summary>

<summary>
• The study aimed to compare the effect of photodynamic diode laser and other smear layer removal methods on the bond strength of self-adhesive cement.
	• The results showed that the photodynamic diode laser and 37% orthophosphoric acid groups had higher bond strength values.
	• The null hypothesis was rejected, indicating that different smear layer removal methods affect the bond strength of a fiber post cemented with adhesive resin to dentin.

• The study found that the smear layer removal methods had varying effects on the bond strength.
	• Sodium hypochlorite and EDTA were not effective in removing the smear layer, while 37% orthophosphoric acid and the photodynamic diode laser were more effective.
	• The photodynamic diode laser showed post-cement failure, while the other groups showed mixed failures.

• The use of the photodynamic diode laser in post space increased the bond strength of resin cement to dentin interface.
	• The laser treatment modified the smear layer, allowing for better infiltration of the luting agent.
	• The results suggest that modifying the smear layer may be more effective than removing it when using a self-adhesive system.

• The study's findings have implications for post restoration success.
	• Improving the bonding effectiveness of the resin and dentin is crucial for post restoration success.
	• The removal of the smear layer and formation of the resin-dentin interdiffusion zone are important factors in achieving successful post restoration.

• The study's results are consistent with previous research on the use of lasers in root canal treatment.
	• Laser devices have been used in root canal treatment since the early 1970s, but their acceptance has been slow due to concerns about thermal damage.
	• The use of lower irradiation power in this study avoided temperature rise and improved bonding effectiveness at the cement-dentin interface.
</summary>

<summary>
* Onychomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the nail, characterized by nail discoloration, thickening, and defect, with dermatophytes, yeasts, and nondermatophytes as the involved pathogens.
	*The most common agents of onychomycosis are dermatophytes such as Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes, accounting for 50-90% of cases.
	*The prevalence of the infection is higher in toenails than in fingernails, and aging and reduced peripheral circulation are among the major risk factors.

* The treatment of onychomycosis is sometimes difficult because the predisposing factors are not influenced by therapy, and it is usually treated with topical or systemic antifungals.
	*Local treatment requires strong patient adherence because the treatment time is generally long, and onychomycosis-related subungueal hyperkeratosis is generally thick, limiting the penetration of the antimycotic drug.
	*Long-term treatments can discourage or induce stopping of the therapy before healing is achieved.

* Tazarotene is a synthetic third-generation retinoid derived from vitamin A, which has proved to be beneficial in modulating keratinocyte proliferation and in reducing inflammation.
	*Tazarotene is used for the treatment of acne, nonmelanoma skin tumors, and inflammatory skin diseases such as psoriasis, and its effect is mediated by the intracellular upregulation of cellular retinoic acid-binding protein-II expression.
	*Tazarotene can exert a protective action on the microvascular bed against fungal infection, similarly to that reported for psoriasis patients.

* The study reports the therapeutic efficacy of tazarotene 0.1% gel for the topical treatment of distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis, with complete healing after 12 weeks, and a rapid and progressive amelioration of all evaluated clinical parameters.
	*The study also documents the fungistatic activity of tazarotene in vitro, supporting the theoretical assumption about its direct action on fungus replication.
	*Tazarotene could be useful in those patients with treatment-resistant forms of onychomycosis or in those with evident enhanced nail thickening, wherein the therapeutic reducing action of the retinoid can be providential.
</summary>

<summary>
• Cardiac resynchronisation therapy (CRT) is an important treatment for patients with heart failure and left ventricular (LV) dyssynchrony, but clinical non-response to CRT is reported in 25-35% of patients.
	• The study aimed to investigate the acute haemodynamic response (AHR) of the implanted system and alternative left ventricular endocardial pacing sites in patients clinically not responding to CRT.

• The study included 24 non-consecutive patients who underwent an acute haemodynamic study to evaluate the effectiveness of CRT and alternative pacing sites.
	• The patients were clinically non-responders to CRT, with a mean age of 72.8 years and a mean ejection fraction of 22.5%.

• The results showed that in 5 patients, LVDP/DTmax with the implanted coronary sinus system increased >15% after optimisation, with an average increase of 30.2%.
	• However, in 3 out of these 5 patients, endocardial pacing did not increase LVDP/DTmax substantially, and in one patient, an adverse effect was observed.

• The study found that basal or mid-posterolateral segments had the highest AHR of the tested endocardial sites in all 14 patients who showed an AHR >15% rise in LVDP/DTmax compared with baseline.
	• The longest time interval between the onset of the QRS complex and LV sensing (Q-LV interval) resulted in the best haemodynamic response in 12 out of the 14 patients.

• Ten patients were considered possible candidates for LV endocardial pacing, and 5 of them finally agreed to LV endocardial implant at the optimal LV site as indicated from the acute study.
	• All five patients improved clinically with a reduction of at least 1 class in the NYHA score after 6 months of follow-up.

• The study demonstrated the importance of lead location, as the clinical response improved with a posterolateral position of the lead instead of the original apical or anterolateral lead location.
	• Conversely, none of the patients who already had a coronary sinus lead in a posterolateral position improved sufficiently with endocardial pacing at any site during the acute haemodynamic study.

• The study showed that endocardial pacing opposite epicardial sites does not show acute haemodynamic improvement, so epicardial pacing at the optimal site may be a good alternative for endocardial LV lead placement.

* The study investigated the effects of nordihydroguaiaretic acid (NDGA) on the lifespan of mice and drosophila.
	* NDGA was found to extend the median lifespan of mice by 12% at a dose of 373mg/kg body weight/day, but had no effect on maximum lifespan.

* The study also found that NDGA increased the incidence of liver, lung, and thymus tumors, and hemorrhagic diathesis in mice.
	* However, NDGA decreased the size of liver tumors by 24% relative to those found in control mice.

* The effects of NDGA on drosophila lifespan were also investigated, and it was found that NDGA increased the median lifespan of flies by approximately 23%.
	* NDGA did not affect food consumption, body weight, or locomotor activity in flies.

* The study suggests that the target(s) of NDGA action are phylogenically conserved between mice and flies.
	* However, the mechanisms of action of NDGA in mice and flies may differ.

* The study also investigated the toxicity of NDGA in mice and found that it did not produce signs of acute liver or kidney toxicity at the concentrations used.
	* However, NDGA did produce elevated triglyceride and glucose levels, which may be related to its effects on energy homeostasis.

* The study discusses possible mechanisms for the longevity effects of NDGA, including inhibition of mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1) and reduction of oxidative stress.
	* However, the study notes that the data are not yet sufficient to determine the exact mechanisms of action of NDGA.

* Biomarkers are characteristics that can be objectively measured and evaluated as indicators of normal biological processes, pathogenic processes, or pharmacologic responses to a therapeutic intervention.
	*Biomarkers can be used for diagnosis, prognosis, and prediction of treatment response, and can be classified into different types, such as DNA biomarkers, DNA tumor biomarkers, and general biomarkers.
	*The development and validation of biomarkers require a rigorous process, including discovery, assay development, and retrospective and prospective validation.

* The development of biomarkers involves several phases, including discovery, assay development, and retrospective and prospective validation.
	*The discovery phase involves the identification of potential biomarkers, while the assay development phase involves the development of a robust and reproducible assay to measure the biomarker.
	*The retrospective and prospective validation phases involve the evaluation of the biomarker's performance in a clinical setting.

* Biomarkers can be used to guide treatment decisions, and can be classified into different types, such as predictive biomarkers, prognostic biomarkers, and diagnostic biomarkers.
	*Predictive biomarkers predict the likely response to a treatment, while prognostic biomarkers predict the likely course of disease.
	*Diagnostic biomarkers are used to diagnose a disease or condition.

* The use of biomarkers in clinical trials requires careful consideration of study design, including the selection of patients, the choice of treatment, and the evaluation of outcomes.
	*The use of biomarkers can help to identify patients who are most likely to benefit from a particular treatment, and can help to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a treatment.
	*The development of biomarkers requires collaboration between researchers, clinicians, and industry partners.

* The reporting of biomarker studies requires careful consideration of study design, methods, and results, and should follow established guidelines, such as the STARD statement.

• Myosin Va (MyoVa) is a processive molecular motor involved in intracellular cargo transport along the actin cytoskeleton.
	• MyoVa's directed movement is accomplished by a conformational change in the motor domain following ATP hydrolysis.
	• The motion is amplified by the lever arms, resulting in the motor's processive motion as each head takes 72 nm steps in a hand-over-hand fashion.
	• Calcium is required to activate the ATPase activity of MyoVa; however, in the presence of high calcium (> 1 μM), motor processivity is reduced.

• The flexural stiffness of MyoVa constructs and subdomains was measured using tethered particle microscopy (TPM).
	• The lever arm flexural stiffness was estimated to be 0.0346 pN/nm, with a corresponding persistence length of 242 nm.
	• The addition of calcium led to a 40% reduction in lever arm flexural stiffness, indicating a substantial decrease in stiffness.
	• The distal rod segment was found to have a flexural stiffness of 0.0326 pN/nm, and the lever arm/rod junction was found to be highly compliant.</summary>

* The study aimed to determine whether clinical outcome after surgical resection of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) could be predicted by functional polymorphisms in different proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes.
	* Six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the AURKA, ERBB2, MDM2, CDH1, CDKN2A, and TP73 genes were genotyped in a consecutive cohort of 346 esophageal cancer patients.
	* Associations with disease-free survival (DFS) were analyzed with Kaplan-Meier curves and Cox regression, adjusting for potential confounders.

* Univariate analysis showed no significant associations between the tested polymorphisms and DFS in patients with EAC or ESCC.
	* However, in a multivariate analysis, patients with EAC carrying the heterozygous MDM2 (rs2279744) T/G genotype had significantly improved DFS compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype.
	* Patients with EAC harboring the homozygous CDH1 (rs5030625) GA/GA genotype had a significantly reduced survival as compared with patients carrying the wild-type genotype.

* The study suggests that inter-individual differences in germ-line DNA have an impact on DFS in patients with EAC.
	* The results indicate that two of six investigated functional polymorphisms are associated with DFS in patients who underwent esophagectomy for EAC.
	* Patients with EAC carrying the heterozygous MDM2 T/G genotype had a twofold reduced risk of disease recurrence, and patients with the homozygous CDH1 GA/GA had a fourfold increased risk of disease recurrence.

* The study highlights the importance of identifying patients who are at high or low risk for the development of disease recurrences.
	* Early detection of recurrent disease is desirable because aggressive treatment may result in prolonged tumor-free survival or occasional cure.
	* Identification of polymorphisms associated with DFS could serve well as hypothesis generating for prospective studies that evaluate the prognostic significance of germ-line variants.

* The study has limitations, including the relatively small sample size and the use of formalin-fixed and paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tissue samples.
	* Collection of blood samples or fresh frozen tissue samples of esophageal cancer patients is necessary and should become standard procedure in order to perform genome-wide association studies.

• Oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) is a common opportunistic fungal infection in HIV-positive patients, with a prevalence of over 90% in this population.
	• The infection is often associated with low CD4+ cell counts, with 73% of patients having cell counts < 200 cells/mm.

• The most common clinical presentation of OPC is pseudomembranous candidiasis, followed by erythematous and angular cheilitis.
	• Candida albicans is the most frequently isolated species in OPC, accounting for 92% of cases in this study.

• The use of antiretroviral therapy (ART) has been shown to reduce the incidence of OPC, but the infection remains a significant problem in HIV-positive patients.
	• The study highlights the need for continued awareness of OPC as a major clinical sign in the HIV population.

• The study's findings are consistent with previous reports, which have also shown that OPC is more common in patients with low CD4+ cell counts and that Candida albicans is the most frequently isolated species.
	• The study's results emphasize the importance of monitoring CD4+ cell counts and providing appropriate treatment for OPC in HIV-positive patients.

<summary>
• Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, with approximately 1.67 million new patients diagnosed annually worldwide.
	• It accounts for 25% of all cancer cases.
	• The status of locoregional lymph nodes is important for staging of the disease and determining prognosis.
	• Sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs) are the first draining nodes from a primary tumor.

• Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is the standard method for determining axillary staging in early-stage breast cancer patients.
	• The combined technique of radioisotope and blue dye is used for SLNB.
	• The tracers are detected within the SLNs by the surgeon using a handheld scintillation counter and/or visually.
	• The gamma probe is used to transcutaneously localize the SLNs and determine the optimal incision site.

• The use of radioisotopes is subject to stringent regulations and many hospitals do not have access to them.
	• Only approximately 60% of patients in the Western world and negligible numbers in the rest of the world have access to SLNB.
	• This has led to the search for other techniques, not reliant on the use of radioisotopes.
	• A magnetic tracer and a handheld magnetometer have been evaluated as a radiation-free alternative.

• Three different-sized superparamagnetic iron oxide (SPIO)-based formulations were used as magnetic tracers in this study.
	• Feraheme/Rienso, Sienna+, and Endorem/Feridex were used as magnetic tracers.
	• The particles have different magnetic cores and coatings.
	• The hydrodynamic particle size of all tracers was determined by dynamic light scattering.

• The study used a previously developed and validated porcine model that closely resembles human lymphatic drainage.
	• Mini-pigs were injected with one of the three different magnetic tracers subcutaneously bilaterally into the areolas of the third inguinal mammary glands.
	• Transcutaneous magnetometer measurements were undertaken in the inguinal region.
	• The sites at which uptake of SPIO was successfully detected were marked using a permanent marker.

• A total of 36 SLNB procedures were performed in 18 mini-pigs, and SLN identification was successful in all cases.
	• In vivo magnetic hotspots from the draining inguinal lymph nodes were successfully identified transcutaneously prior to surgical excision.

• The study analyzed data from two multicenter, double-blind, randomized clinical trials to test surrogate variables for neuropathic diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and explore the correlation between granulation tissue development and complete healing.
	• The trials included 190 ulcers from 190 patients with Wagner grade 3 or 4 DFUs, who received intralesional injections of recombinant human epidermal growth factor (rhEGF) or a placebo.
	• The study also included an active postmarketing surveillance of rhEGF treatment in 1,440 DFUs from 60 healthcare units.
	• The median age of the patients was over 60 years, and the median ulcer size was 22 cm.
	• The study found that granulation tissue development was a strong predictor of complete wound closure, with a correct classification rate of 79.5% at the end of treatment.
		• The proportion of granulation tissue covering the wound area at the end of treatment was the most efficient predictor, with a high negative predictive value (93.5%).

• The study used several statistical models to analyze the data, including logistic regression and receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis.
	• The results of the study suggest that granulation tissue development can be used as a surrogate endpoint for complete wound closure in clinical trials of DFU treatments.
	• The study's findings have implications for clinical trial design and healthcare programs managing DFUs.
• The study's results are consistent with previous research on the role of granulation tissue in wound healing.

	• However, the cutoff points for classification were not the same as those proposed by previous authors.
• The study's limitations include the small sample size and the fact that the partial areas were not measured in routine clinical practice.
	• Further research is needed to validate the surrogate property of granulation tissue development in larger and more diverse populations.
	• The study's findings have implications for the development of new treatments for DFUs and for healthcare programs managing DFUs.

<summary>
* Laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) mesh repair is a standard treatment for inguinal hernia in adults, but it can cause early postoperative pain and chronic pain.
	*The pain is associated with surgical trauma to the abdominal wall, mesh implantation, and mesh fixation in the groin region.

* The ideal mesh material is still being debated, but mesh fixation with fibrin glue or self-fixating mesh with microhooks has advantages in reducing chronic groin pain.
	*These methods can reduce the risk of chronic pain and improve patient outcomes.

* The use of smaller trocars can reduce surgical trauma and improve patient outcomes.
	*Smaller trocars can reduce the risk of local nerve or vessel injury and port-site hernia.

* Modified TAPP repairs by needlescopic surgery (NTAPP) have been shown to be superior to conventional TAPP repairs.
	*NTAPP uses smaller trocars and can reduce surgical trauma and improve patient outcomes.

* Single-incision laparoscopic surgery (STAPP) has also been used for inguinal hernia repair, but it has some limitations.
	*STAPP can be more technically challenging and may require additional trocars.

* A study compared NTAPP and STAPP repairs in 85 patients with single-sided primary inguinal hernia.
	*The study found that NTAPP had a shorter operative time and less postoperative pain than STAPP.

* The study also found that NTAPP had a shorter period of sick leave and less postoperative wound pain than STAPP.
	*However, both groups had similar results in terms of hernia recurrence, abdominal wall mobility, and cosmetic satisfaction.

* The study suggests that NTAPP may be a better option for inguinal hernia repair due to its reduced surgical trauma and improved patient outcomes.
	*However, further studies are needed to confirm these findings and to compare NTAPP with conventional TAPP repairs.

* The study highlights the importance of considering patient-related outcomes such as pain, cosmetic satisfaction, and length of disability when evaluating surgical techniques.
	*These outcomes can be subjective and influenced by multiple factors, including psychological factors and patient motivation.
</summary>

• The breathing process is essential for human survival, and mouth breathing can lead to pathological adaptations in the stomatognathic system.
	• Mouth breathing in childhood can cause maxillary hypoplasia, posterior mandibular demotion, and dental occlusion alterations.
	• These adaptations can lead to functional changes in the stomatognathic system, including alterations in speech, chewing, and deglutition.

• The main causes of mouth breathing in childhood include hypertrophy of the pharyngeal and/or palatine tonsil, nasal mucosa and turbinate edema, nasal septal deviation, and extended suction habits.
	• Accurate diagnosis of the cause of mouth breathing is essential for effective treatment.
	• A multidisciplinary approach is necessary for the diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, and prevention of mouth breathing in childhood.

• Nasopharyngoscopy is considered the gold standard exam for assessing the nasopharynx, providing a dynamic and tridimensional view of the pharyngeal tonsil and its relation to other structures.
	• Cephalometry is a complementary exam that provides information about craniofacial growth and can document and monitor morphofunctional modifications related to mouth breathing.
	• However, cephalometry tends to underestimate the size of the pharyngeal tonsil compared to nasopharyngoscopy.

• The study found a regular and positive correlation between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry in diagnosing the grade of hyperplasia in the pharyngeal tonsils.
	• The sensitivity of cephalometry was 35%, and the negative predictive value was 72%.
	• A negative cephalometric exam may not provide a proper assessment of the nasopharynx when compared to the nasopharyngoscopic exam.

• Nasopharyngoscopy is suggested for patients presenting with mouth-breathing symptoms and normal radiography, as it provides greater diagnostic accuracy due to its tridimensional and dynamic nature.
	• Cephalometry is useful for the initial diagnosis and for monitoring facial growth and dental occlusion.
	• A multidisciplinary approach is necessary for the care of mouth-breathing patients, including physicians, phonoaudiologists, odontologists, and physiotherapists.

<summary>
• Ipsilateral Breast Tumor Relapse (IBTR)
	• IBTR is estimated to occur in less than 6% of patients previously treated for breast carcinoma through breast-conserving surgery, systemic adjuvant therapy, and radiation therapy.
	• IBTR can be classified into two distinct types of lesions: True Local Recurrence (TR) and New Primary Tumor (NPT), which have different natural histories, prognosis, and therapeutic management.
	• The classification of IBTR into TR or NPT is based on pathologic features, location of the new tumor, and genetic sequencing.

• Treatment and Prognosis of IBTR
	• Salvage mastectomy is the standard treatment for all types of IBTR, providing locoregional control in 90% of patients.
	• Patients with TR have a poor prognosis and may benefit from more aggressive adjuvant treatment, while patients with NPT generally have a favorable prognosis and therapeutic decisions should be similar to those in patients with de novo breast carcinoma.
	• Adjuvant tamoxifen has been shown to reduce contralateral and ipsilateral disease recurrence in patients with NPT.

• Follow-up and Care of Breast Cancer Survivors
	• The care of breast cancer survivors requires an understanding of relapse patterns, establishing appropriate follow-up visits, and screening tests.
	• Patients with NPT are at higher risk of developing contralateral breast carcinoma and may benefit from better chemoprevention strategies.
	• Regular follow-up and screening are essential for early detection and treatment of IBTR and contralateral breast cancer.</summary>

<summary>
* Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of severe vision loss in people aged 55 years and older in developed countries.
	*The neovascular form of AMD accounts for the majority of cases of AMD-related severe central vision loss.
	*Upregulation of angiogenic factors, including vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), has been implicated in the development and progression of AMD.
	*Intravitreal anti-VEGF treatment is significantly more effective in preventing progressive vision loss from neovascular AMD than previous alternative treatment modalities.

* The management of neovascular AMD involves the use of continuing anti-VEGF treatment to control signs of exudation by blocking the growth of abnormal blood vessels to prevent vision loss and potentially improve visual acuity (VA).
	*Intravitreal anti-VEGF agents ranibizumab and aflibercept are Health Canada-approved options for the treatment of neovascular AMD.
	*Large multicenter clinical trials have demonstrated that monthly ranibizumab prevents vision loss in most patients with neovascular AMD, with significant visual gain achieved in some.
	*Aflibercept has a greater potency in vitro and a longer duration of action, allowing potentially for less frequent dosing.

* A study was conducted to determine and evaluate change from baseline to week 12 in Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity (CS) as the primary clinical end point in patients with recalcitrant exudative AMD, despite previous ranibizumab treatment, who were switched to aflibercept therapy.
	*The study found a statistically significant improvement in the primary outcome end point of change in CS from baseline to week 12.
	*There was a statistically significant decrease in mean central retinal thickness (CRT) from baseline to week 12.
	*Two-thirds of patients experienced an overall improvement in National Eye Institute 25-item Visual Function Questionnaire (NEI VFQ-25) composite score from baseline to week 12.

* The study results demonstrate that switching to aflibercept from ranibizumab may be a viable treatment strategy to improve outcomes among initial nonresponders or for patients exhibiting recalcitrant exudative disease activity on continued anti-VEGF treatment.
	*VA and CS should be considered as significant independent parameters for determining degree of visual impairment and treatment response.
	*CS determination is a standardized technique that is straightforward and reproducible, and should be more widely considered as a valuable additional outcome

<summary>
• Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a common autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system, causing severe cognitive and physical impairments.
	• It is a chronic disease that affects young adults, with most patients diagnosed between the ages of 20 and 40.
	• The exact cause of MS is unknown, but genetic and environmental factors, such as viruses, are thought to be involved in its pathogenesis.
	• Researchers have investigated the role of interleukin-25 (IL-25) in the immune system and its potential association with MS.
	• IL-25 is a cytokine that plays a key role in stimulating and developing T helper 2 (Th2) responses, which can regulate Th1 and Th17 responses.
	• Th2 responses can improve the clinical and laboratory outcome of MS.

• The study aimed to evaluate the association between the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene and MS in an Iranian population.
	• The study used a case-control design, with 74 patients with relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS) and 75 healthy controls.
	• The results showed that the frequency distribution of the genotypes was not statistically different between patients with MS and controls.
	• The logistic regression model found that the odds ratio (OR) of MS development in patients with the ac and aa genotypes was not statistically significant.
	• The study concluded that the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene is not associated with MS.

<summary>
• The study aimed to explore the prevalence of aortic aneurysms (AAs) and determine whether screening for coronary heart disease (CHD) and AAs is necessary in a population with multiple risk factors for CHD in a Korean population.
	• The study included 502 consecutive Korean male hypertensive patients without a history of AA, who underwent non-contrast computed tomography (CT) scans to measure the diameter of the thoracic and abdominal aorta.
	• The results showed that the prevalence of thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA) was 36.5%, while the prevalence of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was 6.0%.
	• The study found that TAA was associated with older age, larger body surface area, and higher diastolic blood pressure, while AAA was associated with dyslipidemia and smoking history.

• The study highlights the need for distinct screening strategies for TAA and AAA according to risk factors and ethnicity.
	• The results suggest that Asians may have a lower prevalence of AAA compared to Caucasians, and that smoking history is a significant risk factor for AAA in Asian populations.
	• The study also emphasizes the importance of considering the etiology of AAs, which may differ between ascending and descending aorta, when developing screening strategies.

• The study has several limitations, including the inability to properly evaluate the very proximal portion of the ascending aorta using non-contrast CT scans.
	• The study was also performed in a population of elderly Asian males with hypertension, and the results may not be applicable to females, other ethnicities, or groups with a low-risk of cardiovascular disease.

• Future research should focus on establishing methods for aortic screening for TAA and strategies for conservative as well as surgical management in elderly hypertensive patients.
	• The study also suggests that further research is needed to clarify the relationship among TAA, AAA, dyslipidemia, serum cholesterol, and statin therapy.</summary>

<summary>
• Endometrial cancer has become the most common invasive malignancy of the female genital tract in developed countries, surpassing cervical cancer.
	• This is due to various factors such as lifestyle changes, obesity, and hormonal imbalances.
	• The effective procedure for reducing morbidity and mortality in endometrial carcinoma is to screen certain groups with risk factors and design a reliable tool suitable for a mass screening program.

• The current study aimed to investigate whether liquid-based SurePath preparation for endometrial cytology test (ECT) can maintain the three-dimensional structure of the endometrium.
	• The study used the SAP-1 device, a direct endometrial sampler, which is especially designed for minimal pain during sampling and meets the requirements for endometrial samplers.

• The study comprised 1514 patients with endometrial carcinoma risk factors who underwent SAP-1 sampling on an outpatient basis, and 375 of these women also underwent D&C or hysteroscopy.
	• The characteristics of the patients, including age distribution, menstrual status, and symptoms and signs, are presented in the study.

• The results showed that adequate specimens obtained using the SAP-1 sampler (96.3%) are superior to those obtained using D&C (76%).
	• The SAP-1 sampler provides more adequate specimens than D&C or hysteroscopic biopsy, especially in postmenopausal women.

• The study also evaluated the accuracy of cytology for detecting endometrial precursor and carcinoma, which was estimated at 91.7%, sensitivity at 73.6%, specificity at 94.9%, PPV at 71.9%, and NPV at 95.3%.
	• The results demonstrate that the SAP-1 sampler combined with the liquid-based SurePath preparation method is a reliable diagnostic method.

• The main reasons for the lower accuracy of this study compared to previous studies are the patients with positive results, including atypical cells, who underwent hysteroscopic biopsy and D&C, and some of them were subsequently diagnosed as normal or benign.
	• Other methods, including enlarging the sample quantity to collect more information, should be investigated using immunohistochemistry and biochemistry to improve the accuracy of endometrial cytology.

• The study concludes that the SAP-1 sampler combined with SurePath preparation may become a reliable method for screening endometrial carcinoma and its precursor, especially in postmenopausal and asymptomatic women.

<summary>
* Breast cancer is the most common cancer worldwide among women, with nearly 1.7 million new cases in 2012, and the highest incidence rates are in Europe and North America.
	*The highest incidence rates by country are in Belgium, Denmark, and France.
	*Breast cancer mortality has decreased in some parts of the world, with screening mammography associated with an up-to-50% reduction in mortality rate.

* Digital mammography (DM) is less likely to be lost or damaged and has slightly higher sensitivity than screen-film mammography (SFM).
	*DM is now the most commonly used mammography unit in the US.
	*DM offers some improved benefits in women with dense breast tissue.

* Tomosynthesis, a 3D procedure, may help solve the problem of overlapping tissue in conventional mammography.
	*Tomosynthesis creates image slices of a tissue volume, decreasing the problem of confusing overlapping tissue.
	*The slices are thin, and each is seen as a 1mm plane in sharp focus.

* Digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) is a mammography-based technique that uses breast compression similar to 2D DM.
	*DBT obtains multiple low-dose images using a moving x-ray tube head rotating across the breast in an arc of 15%-50%.
	*The image data are used to reconstruct thin tissue slices.

* The addition of DBT to DM improves the accuracy of interpretation of mammograms.
	*DBT can more clearly depict benign findings than routine screening views.
	*DBT can reduce recall rates and decrease the need for additional imaging.

* DBT may decrease the necessity to perform extra mammogram views to identify the exact location of a breast lesion.
	*Radiation dose and patient comfort would benefit if supplementary mammogram views were no longer necessary.
	*DBT can be done with more patient satisfaction, with up to 50% less compression than DM.

* The radiation dose for the combined examination of conventional mammography and DBT is slightly more than twice the dose of mammography alone.
	*Synthetically reconstructed 2D images can be made from the DBT data, eliminating the need for double exposures.
	*This eliminates the need to do an exposure for a DM, and also drops the radiation dose to that of conventional mammography.

* Contrast-enhanced DBT has shown promising results in evaluating the feasibility of contrast-enhanced DBT.

<summary>
• The study aimed to evaluate the effect of diphenhydramine on cough reflex sensitivity in subjects with acute viral upper respiratory tract infection (URI).
	• The results showed that diphenhydramine significantly inhibited cough reflex sensitivity, with a significant increase in mean log C5 values compared to placebo.

• The study compared the effects of diphenhydramine, dextromethorphan, and placebo on cough reflex sensitivity in 22 adult nonsmokers with acute URI.
	• The study found that diphenhydramine was more effective than dextromethorphan in suppressing cough reflex sensitivity, with both agents administered at standard antitussive doses.

• The study used capsaicin cough challenge testing to measure cough reflex sensitivity, which is a safe and reproducible method.
	• The results of the study suggest that diphenhydramine may be a useful treatment option for acute cough due to URI.

• The study's findings are significant because they provide the first demonstration of diphenhydramine's ability to suppress cough reflex sensitivity in subjects with acute URI.
	• The study's results contribute to the growing body of evidence on the effectiveness of over-the-counter (OTC) cough and cold medications.

• The study's limitations include the small sample size and the fact that the study only measured cough reflex sensitivity 2 hours after study drug administration.
	• Further clinical trials are needed to adequately evaluate the effectiveness of diphenhydramine and other OTC cough and cold products.
</summary>

<summary>
• The global population is getting older, and this trend is predicted to continue, leading to an increased prevalence of cardiovascular diseases.
	• Aging is one of the most important cardiovascular risk factors, predisposing conditions such as diabetes, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia.

• The endothelium plays a primary role in adjusting vascular function by producing nitric oxide (NO) and other biologically active vasodilators.
	• Alterations in the control of these processes often lead to atherosclerosis and other vascular disorders, accompanied by a proinflammatory, proliferative, and procoagulatory state.

• Endothelial dysfunction is defined as functional alterations in endothelial physiology, characterized by a reduction of vasodilator substance output and augmentation in endothelium-derived contracting factors.
	• This imbalance leads to a vasoconstrictive, hypercoagulative, proliferative, and proinflammatory state, favoring atherosclerosis.

• Oxidative stress is an imbalance between the production of oxidizing agents and opposing antioxidant systems, interfering with endothelial function and reducing NO bioavailability.
	• The increased production of superoxide anions in the aging vascular wall rapidly inactivates NO, leading to the formation of cytotoxic peroxynitrite.

• Exercise training prevents and restores age-related impairment of endothelial function, possibly by the restoration of NO availability consequent to prevention of oxidative stress and alleviating inflammatory processes.
	• Regular exercise reduces CRP, IL-6, and TNF- levels while increasing anti-inflammatory substances such as IL-4 and IL-10.

• The role of inflammation during the different phases of atherosclerosis is significant, with markers of inflammation such as high sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) providing additional insights on the biological status of atherosclerotic lesions.
	• Exercise-induced increases in plasma IL-6 correlate with the muscle mass involved in exercise activity and the mode, duration, and intensity of exercise, especially in older individuals.

• Exercise produces a short-term inflammatory response followed by a long-term anti-inflammatory adaptive response, controlling the release and activity of at least two cytokines, TNF- and IL-6.
	• IL-6 acts as both a proinflammatory and anti-inflammatory cytokine, exerting anti-inflammatory effects through its inhibitory effects on TNF- and IL-1, and activation of interleukin-1 receptor antagonist (IL-1ra) and IL-10.
</summary>

<summary>
• The axillary lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor in breast carcinoma, and the prognosis worsens with an increasing number of metastatic lymph nodes.
	• The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC)/International Union Against Cancer (UICC) classifies nodal disease into three groups based on the number of axillary metastatic lymph nodes: N1 (1-3), N2 (4-9), and N3 (10 or more).

• The number of metastatic lymph nodes depends on the number of removed lymph nodes, and various studies have shown that the number of metastatic lymph nodes increases with the number of removed lymph nodes.
	• The ratio of the number of metastatic lymph nodes to the number of removed lymph nodes, denoted as the lymph node ratio (LNR), provides more useful prognostic information than nodal disease classification.

• The LNR threshold value separating patients into two prognostic groups with significantly different survival rates varies in different studies, and the value of 0.20 and 0.25 has been reported.
	• In patients with N2 and N3 disease receiving adjuvant high-dose chemotherapy with stem-cell support, the LNR threshold value of prognostic significance was determined as 0.80 and 0.70.

• The study evaluated the prognostic significance of the number of removed and metastatic lymph nodes and LNR in breast carcinoma patients with 1-3 axillary metastatic lymph nodes.
	• The results showed that the LNR threshold value of 0.20, 0.30, and 0.15 separated patients into low- and high-risk groups with significant survival differences for disease-free survival (DFS), locoregional recurrence-free survival (LRFS), and distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS), respectively.

• The study suggests that LNR can be used to separate patients with N1 disease into low- and high-risk prognostic groups regardless of the total number of lymph nodes removed.
	• The results also indicate that LNR is a more powerful prognostic factor than the number of metastatic lymph nodes and can provide more detailed and useful prognostic information than TNM nodal disease classification.

• The study concludes that LNR is a useful tool in separating breast carcinoma patients with 1-3 metastatic lymph nodes into low- and high-risk prognostic groups, and it may be useful to standardize adjuvant therapy for patients operated in hospitals

	• The use of strong acid derivatives, such as tosylate, mesylate, and triflate, is common but inefficient.
	• Enzymatic phosphorylation by kinases and sulfotransferases is a more efficient method, but it requires molar equivalents of cofactors.
	• The use of acid phosphatases with inorganic polyphosphates as phosphate donors is a promising alternative.
	• This method circumvents the need for cofactor recycling and uses environmentally benign byproducts.
	• It also allows for broad substrate specificity and efficient phosphate transfer.

• The study aimed to evaluate a set of phosphatases as potential candidates for synthetic applications.
	• Various techniques were investigated to enhance product titers and minimize hydrolytic reactions.
	• Enzyme candidates were selected from the family of acid phosphatases, which have been shown to transfer phosphate moieties efficiently.
	• The substrate scope of the selected enzymes was investigated, including primary and secondary alcohols and sugars.
	• The results showed that the enzymes were efficient catalysts in the phosphorylation of various alcohols.
	• The study also explored the effect of reaction parameters, such as pH and phosphate donor type, on product formation.

• The study found that the use of high-energy phosphate donors, such as triphosphate and polyphosphate, increased product titers.
	• The results also showed that the type of phosphate donor and pH had a significant impact on product formation.
	• The study demonstrated that kinetic control of the reaction is crucial to achieve high product titers.
	• The use of a continuous flow reactor was shown to be an efficient tool to maintain high product levels and scale up the reaction.

• The study evaluated several epoxy and amino-functionalized polymeric beads for the covalent immobilization of phosphatases.
	• The results showed that Relizyme HA403/m, an amino-functionalized resin, resulted in the highest specific activity for both enzymes.
	• The immobilized enzyme was applied to the preparative-scale phosphorylation of 1,4-butanediol.
	• The results showed that the enzymatic phosphorylation proceeded with high regioselectivity and absolute chemoselectivity.
	• The study demonstrated the potential of phosphatases for the synthesis of phosphate monoesters.

<summary>
* The concept of non-native biological invaders has been noted for centuries, with examples such as the phylloxera and chestnut blight.
	*The phylloxera destroyed grapevines and devastated the wine industry in Europe in the 1860s.
	*The chestnut blight entered North America in the early 20th century and virtually eliminated a dominant tree species.
	*Charles Elton produced a series of BBC radio broadcasts about non-native invasions in 1957.

* Elton's book did not inspire a broad research thrust on invasions or a widespread public and policy response to their growing number.
	*However, in the mid-1980s, an international project of the Scientific Committee on Problems of the Environment (SCOPE) engaged over 100 prominent scientists worldwide.
	*The project produced several widely read edited volumes and triggered an explosion of research on invasions.
	*Research on invasions soon came to be recognized as one of the great ongoing global environmental changes.

* The surge of research included many studies of how particular non-native invaders eat native species, compete with them, or infect them.
	*Examples include the brown tree snake in Guam, the hemlock woolly adelgid in the eastern US, and whirling disease of rainbow trout in the US.
	*Research also showed that introduced species can sometimes compete with native species while vectoring diseases to them.
	*Examples include signal crayfish in Europe and the gray squirrel in Great Britain.

* Two new lines of research have become increasingly prominent, both indicating that impacts of introduced species are more varied and widespread than had previously been thought.
	*One line of research focuses on the ecosystem level, showing how a single introduced species can change processes or the physical structure of an ecosystem.
	*The other line of research focuses on genetics and evolution, revealing a great number of cases of hybridization and introgression with native species.

* Molecular genetic research has increasingly revealed the "stealth" impact of invaders, hybridization, and introgression with native species.
	*Hybridization between native and introduced species can even produce new, more invasive species.
	*Molecular genetic features such as microsatellites, mitochondrial DNA, and single-nucleotide polymorphisms have been used to trace sources and routes of invasions.
	*Environmental DNA (eDNA) is increasingly used to detect invaders.

* The burst of research in the wake of the SCOPE project also revealed an increasing number of cases of "invasional

  • Schwannomas of the vidian canal are extremely rare tumors that arise from the primary glial cells of the peripheral nervous system, with only 4 documented cases of biopsy-proven vidian nerve schwannomas in the literature.
	• They can present with symptoms such as headaches, facial pain, facial muscle paralysis, decreased lacrimation, and nasal dryness, or as an incidental finding, and treatment options include endoscopic surgical resection, single-fraction stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS), and conventional fractionated radiotherapy using stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT).
</summary>

<summary>
• The study compared the biomechanical performance of monoaxial and polyaxial pedicle screws with or without an intermediate screw at the fractured vertebra in a calf experimental model of an unstable burst fracture.
	• The results showed that the addition of an intermediate screw decreased the range of motion (ROM) of the L2-L4 segments in both the monoaxial and polyaxial pedicle screw groups.
	• The study concluded that the addition of intermediate screws at the level of a burst fracture significantly increases the stability of a short-segment pedicle fixation, using either monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws.

	• The study used 12 fresh-frozen calf lumbar specimens (L1-L5) and created an unstable burst fracture in the L3 vertebra using the pre-injury and dropped-mass technique.
	• The specimens were randomly divided into monoaxial pedicle screw (MPS) group and polyaxial pedicle screw (PPS) group, and two kinds of spinal fixations (with or without intermediate screw placement) were studied in each group.
	• The results showed that the short-segment MPS fixation group was significantly more stable in flexion and extension than the short-segment PPS fixation group.
	• The study suggested that the use of an intermediate screw at the level of fractured vertebrae with posterior short-segment fixation, especially when using monoaxial screws, can provide a biomechanical rationale for fixing unstable burst fractures of the lumbar region.

	• The study had some limitations, including the use of a calf spine model, which may not accurately represent human spine biomechanics.
	• The study only tested the flexibility of the construct immediately after surgery and did not take into account early bone resorption or the cyclical loading effect.
	• The study did not compare the results with long-segment fixations and application of the cross link, which have been shown to have better biomechanical stability than the short segment in managing unstable burst fractures.
	• The study suggested that a prospective clinical study is needed to show the true practical significance of the addition of intermediate screws.
</summary>

• The discovery of electrochemical self-assembly (ESA) of nanostructured hybrid thin films has opened a new synthetic route for obtaining photoanode materials for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs).
	• ESA of ZnO structures has been demonstrated for the construction of photoanodes, and the addition of water-soluble dye molecules has brought about a significant impact on crystal growth and alteration of the crystallographic orientation of the film.
	• The electrodeposited ZnO/dye hybrid thin films exhibited dye-sensitized photocathodic properties, evincing the intimate chemistry between ZnO and dyes having soft basic anchors.

• The ESA of CuSCN-based hybrid thin films has been explored as a counterpart to the well-established ZnO-based hybrid systems.
	• The addition of rhodamine B (RB) to the bath has caused a slight decrease of the steady-state current in the SCN-rich bath, whereas a slight increase of the current was observed in the Cu-rich bath.
	• The loaded RB molecules can almost completely be extracted by dipping the film in dimethylacetamide (DMA), making it highly porous.

• The resulting porous crystalline CuSCN thin film has been utilized as a dye-sensitized photocathode to prove its usefulness as a counterpart of dye-sensitized ZnO photoanodes.
	• The porous nanostructure and crystallographic orientation of CuSCN could be controlled by the choice of the bath composition.
	• The successfully constructed efficient dye-sensitized CuSCN photocathode can be combined with existing dye-sensitized photoanodes to achieve high-efficiency tandem DSSCs in a very simple structure.</summary>

<summary>
• Nasopharyngeal bursa originates from the area of communication between the notochord and the foregut, specifically the pharyngeal endoderm.
	• It is believed to be a remnant of embryonic communication between the notochord and the roof of the pharynx.
	• This communication normally disappears during the second month of intrauterine fetal development.

• A Tornwaldt's cyst develops if the embryonic remnant becomes obstructed, while the crust type forms if crusts adhere to the orifice without obstruction.
	• The crust type sheds periodically, causing an offensive smell and unpleasant taste.
	• Eagle indicated that in the crust type, the orifice of the bursa is not obstructed despite crust formation.

• The cystic type of nasopharyngeal bursitis is more common and should be part of the differential diagnosis of nasopharyngeal abscesses and cysts.
	• Although most patients are symptom-free, some will develop bursitis, a cyst, or an abscess.
	• Symptoms can include nasal obstruction, Eustachian tube obstruction, dysphagia, and cranial nerve paralysis.

• The incidence of nasopharyngeal bursitis is approximately 4% in adults, but it can appear at any age.
	• The peak incidence occurs between 15 and 30 years, with a Caucasian predominance and no gender predilection.
	• Most published literature comprises selected case reports and describes the cystic type.

• A two-year clinicoanatomical audit of nasopharyngeal bursitis was conducted at a rhinology practice in a university unit.
	• All patients diagnosed with nasopharyngeal bursitis were asked about symptoms of Tornwaldt's syndrome.
	• A surgical technique combining an endonasal and transoral approach was performed on patients presenting with either the cyst type or the crust type.

• The audit results indicated that six patients were diagnosed with nasopharyngeal bursitis, with an incidence of less than 1% of all rhinitis patients.
	• Two patients had classical Tornwaldt's cyst, one had a fibrosed Tornwaldt's cyst, and three had crust-type bursitis.
	• Patients who underwent surgery had a complete recovery with no recurrence of symptoms at more than one year postoperatively.

* Melanoma skin cancer has been increasing over the past few decades, with an estimated 76,250 new cases diagnosed in the USA in 2012, resulting in 9,180 deaths.
	*Australia has one of the highest rates of skin cancer in the world.
	*Early diagnosis of melanoma is crucial for prognosis.
	*Dermoscopy is a non-invasive diagnostic technique that enables visualization of morphological features not discernible by the naked eye.

* Dermoscopy enables better diagnosis compared to the unaided eye, with an improvement in diagnostic sensitivity of 10-30%.
	*However, dermoscopy may lower diagnostic accuracy in inexperienced dermatologists.
	*Experts have achieved 90% sensitivity and 59% specificity in skin lesion diagnosis.
	*Less trained doctors have shown a significant drop in sensitivity and specificity.

* Several scoring systems and algorithms have been proposed to improve diagnostic performance, including the ABCD-E rule and the seven-point checklist.
	*These algorithms have shown good accuracy but have problems that have not been solved.
	*The most important shortcoming is the low within- and between-observer concordance.
	*Even expert observers have shown low concordance.

* Automated analysis of digitized images obtained by epiluminescence microscopy (ELM) techniques has been developed to assist clinicians in differentiating early melanoma from benign skin lesions.
	*Application of computational intelligence methods helps physicians and dermatologists in faster data processing and more reliable diagnoses.
	*Studies on automated classification of pigmented skin lesion images have appeared in the literature since 1987.
	*Machine vision and computerized analysis are becoming increasingly important.

* Numerous computerized diagnostic systems have been reported in the literature, using different border detection, feature extraction, selection, and classification algorithms.
	*Some researchers have reviewed and compared image analysis techniques for skin cancer diagnosis.
	*Comparisons of diagnostic accuracy of experts and artificial intelligence have been made.
	*More research is needed to identify and reduce uncertainties in automatic decision support systems.

* A comprehensive review of automatic diagnostic models for skin lesions is not available.
	*Continuous emergence of new classification algorithms and techniques for dermoscopic image analysis necessitates such a review.
	*This paper describes a standard automatic decision support system based on semantic analysis of melanoma images.
	*The aim is to summarize and compare advanced dermoscopic algorithms used for skin lesion classification.

	*The International Diabetes Federation (IDF) reported 366 million people with diabetes worldwide, expected to rise to 552 million by 2030 if no action is taken.
	*90% of patients with diabetes have T2D, resulting from a combination of lifestyle and genetic factors.
	*Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor coactivator 1 (PGC-1) gene is involved in mitochondrial biosynthesis, fatty acid oxidation, and insulin secretion.

	*MFN2 gene is involved in ER-mitochondria juxtaposition and intercommunication during Ca signaling.

* Toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma gondii, with cats as the primary host and humans as intermediate hosts.
	*Most people with toxoplasmosis are asymptomatic.
	*However, if a pregnant woman is infected, the parasite can enter the fetal circulation through the placenta and cause congenital toxoplasmosis.
	*Congenital toxoplasmosis can present with a broad spectrum of clinical manifestations.

* Congenital toxoplasmosis may cause severe central nervous system (CNS) involvement, including hydrocephalus, mental retardation, seizures, and intracerebral calcifications.
	*Seizure is one of the main presenting symptoms in patients with CNS infection of congenital acquired toxoplasmosis.
	*Many patients with congenital toxoplasmosis take anti-epileptic drugs (AED) constantly.

	*This suggested a chronic phase of T. gondii infection.

	*The frequency of her seizures increased over time, despite increasing the dose of AED.

<summary>
• Approximately 20 million people in the US have gallstones, and 1 million new patients are diagnosed with cholelithiasis every year.
	• The treatment of cholelithiasis is the most costly digestive disease, with an estimated annual cost of over $5 billion.
	• The National Institute of Health convened a consensus development conference in 1992 to discuss the treatment of cholelithiasis and laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
	• The conference concluded that laparoscopic cholecystectomy offered substantial advantages over traditional open cholecystectomy with no apparent increase in morbidity or mortality.

• Laparoscopic cholecystectomy reduces pain and disability, resulting in lower treatment costs and substantial savings to patients and society.
	• The shortened period of disability after laparoscopic cholecystectomy reduces costs and increases productivity.
	• Traditional appraisal methods often do not measure the cost of disability and loss of income after open cholecystectomy.
	• Laparoscopic cholecystectomy has greatly reduced the convalescent period and costs associated with open cholecystectomy.

• Charges for laparoscopic cholecystectomy often surpass those of open cholecystectomy, despite lower costs.
	• The excess charges for laparoscopic cholecystectomy are likely due to the cost of equipment and technical requirements.
	• A study at Maricopa Medical Center found that the average charge for converted laparoscopic cholecystectomies was $19,922, compared to $13,042 for open cholecystectomies.
	• The study suggested that the only reason for the increased charges was the cost of laparoscopy.

• A retrospective review of 70 cholecystectomy patients found that the average charge for converted laparoscopic cholecystectomies was $19,922, compared to $13,042 for open cholecystectomies.
	• The study used a paired sample t-test and decision tree analysis to determine the most cost-effective operation.
	• The study found that open cholecystectomy was more cost-effective, but laparoscopic cholecystectomy could become cost-effective if charges were reduced.
	• The study suggested that a reduction in charges of $3,331 would be needed to make laparoscopic cholecystectomy cost-effective.
